Litigation Professional.name: Holding Clarity and Citable Form
Litigation Professional.description: Evaluates whether the summary explicitly states the court's dispositive holding(s) in concise, rule-like form suitable for reliance or citation; assesses clarity when there are multiple holdings and whether the rule is extractable for briefs or headings.

sub_criteria.name: Separation and Numbering of Holdings
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether multiple holdings (if any) are clearly separated, labeled, enumerated, and presented in a hierarchy so a reader can identify each discrete rule.
accepted_values: Multiple holdings clearly separated, numbered, and hierarchically organized
Multiple holdings separated but numbering/hierarchy could be clearer
Multiple holdings present but conflated or inconsistent labeling
No identification or separation of multiple holdings

sub_criteria.name: Citable Language and Brevity
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether each holding is phrased succinctly in citation-ready, rule-like language (black-letter rule) that can be used with minimal editing in briefs, headings, or table of authorities.
accepted_values: Holding phrased in citation-ready, rule-like language requiring no editing
Holding usable with minor editing for direct insertion in briefs/headings
Holding phrased narratively/factually and requires substantial editing
Holding not expressed in a form usable for briefs or citation

sub_criteria.name: Rule vs. Outcome Distinction
sub_criteria.description: Determines whether the summary distinguishes a general legal rule from the case-specific outcome (i.e., indicates which language is the binding rule versus the factual application).
accepted_values: Clear distinction between abstract rule and case outcome provided
Some effort to separate rule from outcome but not fully explicit
Rule and outcome blurred; reader must infer distinction
No distinction between rule and case-specific outcome

sub_criteria.name: Operational Test or Elements Extracted
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary extracts a test, formula, or list of elements from the holding that practitioners can apply to other fact patterns.
accepted_values: Operational test or enumerated elements clearly extracted and usable
Test/elements present but require modest refinement
No operational test or elements extracted

Litigation Professional.name: Procedural Posture and Final Disposition
Litigation Professional.description: Assesses whether the summary identifies the issuing court/level, party posture (who appealed or moved), stage of litigation, final disposition, and remedy, with sufficient specificity to understand procedural context.

sub_criteria.name: Court, Panel/Judge and Jurisdiction
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary specifies the issuing court (e.g., 9th Cir.), panel or judge where relevant, and geographic/institutional jurisdictional reach.
accepted_values: Court, panel/judge, and jurisdiction clearly and precisely stated
Court level and jurisdiction clear; panel/judge partial or parenthetical
Court generally identified but lacks specifics (e.g., 'appeals court')
No court or jurisdictional information provided

sub_criteria.name: Stage of Litigation and Party Posture
sub_criteria.description: Specifies whether the decision arose at trial, summary judgment, interlocutory appeal, appeal from final judgment, or enforcement stage, and identifies appellant/respondent roles and original movants.
accepted_values: Stage and party posture clearly and specifically stated
Stage and posture present but with minor ambiguity
Stage or posture only generally referenced
No stage or party posture provided

sub_criteria.name: Disposition, Remedy and Relief Specificity
sub_criteria.description: Records whether the summary states the disposition (affirmed/reversed/remanded/dismissed) and any relief (damages, injunction) with useful specificity and conditions of relief.
accepted_values: Disposition and remedy clearly and specifically stated with conditions
Disposition or remedy mentioned but incomplete or ambiguous

sub_criteria.name: Appealability and Finality Notes
sub_criteria.description: Notes whether the decision is final or interlocutory and whether further appeal or certiorari is possible/likely, as indicated in the summary.
accepted_values: Finality/appealability explicitly stated and implications noted
Finality indicated but implications for further review limited
No information about appealability or finality

Litigation Professional.name: Procedural History and Preservation Issues
Litigation Professional.description: Evaluates whether the summary presents a clear, chronological account of prior proceedings (motions, rulings, appeals), highlights preservation or waiver issues, and flags procedural defects that affected review or scope of issues considered.

sub_criteria.name: Chronology and Timeline Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether dates and sequence of key procedural events are presented clearly enough to place the decision in context and to trace prior rulings that shaped the appeal.
accepted_values: Dates and sequence provided clearly and unambiguously
Most dates/sequences present with minor ambiguities

sub_criteria.name: Preservation, Waiver, and Procedural Defects
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary identifies whether issues were preserved or waived at earlier stages, and whether timing, jurisdictional, or procedural defects affected the review or outcome.
accepted_values: Preservation/waiver and procedural defects clearly identified and explained
Some preservation/defects noted but explanation limited
No mention of preservation, waiver, or procedural defects

sub_criteria.name: Identification of Pivotal Procedural Rulings
sub_criteria.description: Highlights which earlier procedural rulings (denial of leave, denial of interlocutory appeal, remand orders) materially shaped the appeal or outcome and explains their effect.
accepted_values: Pivotal procedural rulings clearly identified and their impact explained
Some pivotal rulings noted but explanation limited
Possible pivotal rulings mentioned without clear linkage
No identification of pivotal procedural rulings

sub_criteria.name: Prior Court Findings and Effect on Present Review
sub_criteria.description: Indicates whether and how findings or factual determinations by lower courts constrained appellate review (e.g., factual findings accepted under clear error).
accepted_values: Prior findings and their effect on appellate review explicitly explained
Prior findings mentioned but linkage to standard of review limited
Lower-court findings referenced without clear import
No reference to prior court findings or their effect

Litigation Professional.name: Material Facts — Relevance and Completeness
Litigation Professional.description: Determines whether the summary distinguishes legally material facts from background, presents them succinctly, and includes all core facts necessary to follow the court's application of law.

sub_criteria.name: Relevance Filtering
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary emphasizes legally relevant facts and omits unnecessary detail that would distract a practitioner.
accepted_values: Material facts clearly highlighted and peripheral details minimized
Material facts present but some extraneous detail included
Material and background facts mixed; reader must parse
No effective filtering of relevant facts

sub_criteria.name: Completeness for Reasoning
sub_criteria.description: Checks that essential factual elements relied upon by the court's reasoning are included so a reader can follow legal analysis and determine applicability to other cases.
accepted_values: All facts essential to the court's reasoning are present
Most essential facts included with minor omissions
Key factual elements missing affecting understanding

sub_criteria.name: Conciseness and Readability of Facts
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the facts are presented concisely in a format conducive to quick comprehension (e.g., short paragraphs, bullets, timelines).
accepted_values: Facts concise and easy to scan
Often verbose; could be substantially shortened
Overly long and difficult to parse quickly

sub_criteria.name: Parties, Roles, and Key Dates
sub_criteria.description: Ensures that parties are clearly identified (plaintiff/defendant, individual v. corporate), their roles explained, and key dates (contracts, injuries, filings) included.
accepted_values: Parties, roles, and key dates clearly and specifically stated
Parties and roles clear but some key dates missing
Parties vaguely described or dates incomplete
No clear identification of parties or key dates

Litigation Professional.name: Issue Statements and Issue Organization
Litigation Professional.description: Assesses the precision, number, and organization of issue statements — whether legal questions are framed narrowly and actionably for drafting briefs or headings, and whether multiple issues are distinct and prioritized.

sub_criteria.name: Precision and Narrowness
sub_criteria.description: Measures whether each issue is framed narrowly in legal terms rather than as a broad outcome statement, and whether statutory or doctrinal phrasing is used where appropriate.
accepted_values: Issue(s) stated precisely and narrowly in legal terms

sub_criteria.name: Actionability for Headings/Motion Drafting
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether an issue statement can be used directly or with minimal edits as a point heading, motion statement, or brief theme.
accepted_values: Directly usable as a brief/motion heading with no edits
Needs substantial refinement to be usable

sub_criteria.name: Numbering, Prioritization and Distinction of Multiple Issues
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether multiple issues are numbered, separated, prioritized by importance, and each framed distinctly to aid navigation and argument planning.
accepted_values: Multiple issues clearly numbered, prioritized, and distinct
Issues present but organization/prioritization could be clearer
Issues muddled together without clear priority
No organization or numbering of issues

sub_criteria.name: Neutral/Client-Focused Framing
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether issues are neutrally stated for legal analysis yet can be reframed quickly to suit client-side perspectives (plaintiff/defendant) if needed.
accepted_values: Issues neutrally framed and easily reframed for client-focused argument
Neutral framing present but requires some reframing for client use
Framing biased or oriented such that reframing is awkward
Issues framed in a way not useful for client argument

Litigation Professional.name: Legal Rules, Elements, Tests, and Standard of Review
Litigation Professional.description: Evaluates whether the summary states the governing legal rules, enumerates elements or factors, identifies the applicable standard of review, and attributes sources (statute, case, regulation) sufficiently for drafting and legal analysis.

sub_criteria.name: Rule and Test Identification
sub_criteria.description: Whether the governing rule(s) or doctrinal test(s) are named and explained as applied by the court, including whether the court announced a new rule or applied existing doctrine.
accepted_values: Governing rules/tests explicitly identified and their application explained
Rule/test identified but application summarized briefly
Rule/test only implied or vaguely referenced

sub_criteria.name: Elements/Factors Enumerated and Mapped
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the elements or factors of a rule are clearly listed and explicitly linked to the facts in the summary.
accepted_values: Elements/factors fully enumerated and explicitly linked to facts
Most elements listed; linkage to facts partial
Elements mentioned but incomplete or unlinked
No listing of elements or factors

sub_criteria.name: Standard of Review and Its Effect
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the applicable standard of review (de novo, abuse of discretion, clear error, substantial evidence) is named and whether the summary explains how that standard influenced the result.
accepted_values: Standard named for relevant issues and linkage to outcome explained
Standard named but linkage to outcome limited
Standard only implied or mentioned without effect
No mention of standard of review

sub_criteria.name: Source Attribution (Statutes/Cases/Regs) and Citation-Ready References
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary attributes rules to precise sources with usable citation information (statute section, case name/page), enabling a drafter to locate the primary source without major additional research.
accepted_values: Rules attributed to precise sources with usable citations and section numbers
Sources mentioned but citation details incomplete
Source attribution vague (no specifics) or only informal references

sub_criteria.name: Novelty and Doctrinal Impact
sub_criteria.description: Indicates whether the decision is doctrinally novel or presents incremental application of existing law, and whether the summary notes the practical significance of novelty.
accepted_values: Some indication of novelty but limited explanation
Novelty hinted at but not clarified
No indication of novelty or doctrinal impact

Litigation Professional.name: Reasoning, Use of Precedent, and Counterarguments
Litigation Professional.description: Evaluates whether the summary captures the court's chain of reasoning, how precedent was used (distinguished/followed/overruled), and summarizes the court's treatment of counterarguments and policy considerations.

sub_criteria.name: Chain of Reasoning and Key Inferential Steps
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary preserves the logical steps from premises to conclusion so a reader can follow why the court reached its holding, including intermediate inferences and factual-to-legal links.
accepted_values: Chain of reasoning clearly and faithfully captured with key inferential steps
Major steps present but some inferential gaps remain
Reasoning abridged losing important steps and context

sub_criteria.name: Treatment and Role of Precedent
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary explains how the court treated prior authorities (followed, distinguished, limited, or overruled) and the weight given to them in analysis.
accepted_values: Precedent use clearly explained and linked to the court's analysis
Some precedent noted but the role not fully explained
Precedent mentioned only in passing without analysis

sub_criteria.name: Engagement with Counterarguments and Alternatives
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary notes the court's responses to opposing arguments, alternative rationales, or policy objections and whether the summary reflects the court's reasons for rejecting them.
accepted_values: Court's engagement with counterarguments clearly summarized and linked to outcome
Some counterarguments noted but not fully addressed
Counterarguments mentioned briefly without substantive explanation
No mention of counterarguments or alternative reasoning

sub_criteria.name: Policy, Purpose, and Interpretive Methodology
sub_criteria.description: Identifies whether the court relied on policy arguments, statutory purpose, or a particular interpretive methodology (textualism, purposivism), and whether the summary captures that approach.
accepted_values: Policy/purpose and interpretive method explicitly identified and tied to reasoning
Some mention of policy or method but limited linkage
Method or policy hinted at but not explained
No mention of policy or interpretive methodology

Litigation Professional.name: Citations, Pinpoints, and Source Details
Litigation Professional.description: Assesses whether the summary includes the case citation and pinpoint references, parallel or neutral citations, and precise statutory/regulatory references as presented, enabling quick location and verification of sources.

sub_criteria.name: Case Citation Completeness
sub_criteria.description: Checks for the presence of a full case citation (parties, reporter, volume, page, year) or a neutral citation where applicable, as included in the summary.
accepted_values: Complete, standard citation included (party names, reporter, volume, page, year or neutral citation)
Citation present but missing minor elements (e.g., year or reporter abbreviation)

sub_criteria.name: Pinpoint/Paragraph References for Key Holdings and Quotes
sub_criteria.description: Whether pinpoints (page/paragraph/section) are provided for holdings, key quotes, or pivotal passages to allow precise referencing.
accepted_values: Pinpoints provided for key holdings and quotations consistently
Some pinpoints present but not comprehensive

sub_criteria.name: Statute/Regulation Citation Precision
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether statutory or regulatory provisions referenced are cited to exact section/subsection identifiers and whether relevant subsection language is excerpted or paraphrased correctly.
accepted_values: Statutes/regulations cited with precise section/subsection identifiers and excerpted when helpful
Statutes/regulations mentioned but without full pinpointing

sub_criteria.name: Parallel Citations and Subsequent History (as Reported)
sub_criteria.description: Determines whether the summary includes any parallel citations and any subsequent history or treatment mentioned in the summary itself (without independent verification).
accepted_values: Parallel citations and subsequent history included as reported in the summary
Some parallel/subsequent history included but incomplete
No parallel citations or subsequent history reported

sub_criteria.name: Secondary and Secondary-source References
sub_criteria.description: Notes whether important secondary sources (Restatements, treatises, law review articles) referenced by the court or useful for context are included or cited in the summary.
accepted_values: Secondary sources referenced and cited with usable detail
Some secondary sources mentioned but citation details limited

Litigation Professional.name: Jurisdictional Weight and Precedential Character
Litigation Professional.description: Evaluates whether the summary specifies the jurisdictional reach, binding or persuasive weight of the decision for relevant forums, and any caveats (panel decisions, en banc, unpublished) as stated in the summary.

sub_criteria.name: Jurisdiction and Court Level Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary states the geographic and institutional reach (state vs federal, circuit, district, supreme court) of the decision.
accepted_values: Jurisdiction and court level clearly and unambiguously stated
Jurisdiction stated but with minor ambiguity

sub_criteria.name: Binding vs. Persuasive Characterization (as Stated)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary explains, based on case text included, whether the authority is binding or persuasive for various forums (e.g., in-circuit vs out-of-circuit, unpublished/nonprecedential).
accepted_values: Precedential weight explicitly described along with caveats (unpublished, en banc, panel limits)
Precedential status mentioned but explanation limited
Precedential character implied but not clear

sub_criteria.name: Reported Subsequent Treatment or Status (as Included)
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary itself reports any subsequent treatment (rehearing, certiorari action, later overruling/limiting decisions) without requiring external verification.
accepted_values: Subsequent treatment/status reported clearly in the summary
Some subsequent treatment mentioned but details limited
Subsequent status hinted at but unclear

sub_criteria.name: Temporal/Statutory Applicability (Changes Since Decision)
sub_criteria.description: Indicates whether the summary notes whether changes in statute/regulation or intervening precedent might limit current applicability (as stated in the summary).
accepted_values: Temporal or statutory limitations noted with clear implications
Some mention of intervening changes but limited explanation
Possible changes hinted at but not explained

Litigation Professional.name: Scope, Distinguishers, and Predictive Guidance
Litigation Professional.description: Assesses whether the summary identifies doctrinal and factual limits of the decision, lists concrete factual distinguishers, and offers practical guidance on where the holding is likely to apply or not apply (as presented in the summary).

sub_criteria.name: Doctrinal Limits and Breadth
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary explains whether the holding is narrow or broad and why, based on the court's language included in the summary.
accepted_values: Scope clearly characterized (narrow/broad) with supporting rationale
Scope only implied without clear explanation
No discussion of scope or doctrinal limits

sub_criteria.name: Factual Distinguishers — Actionability
sub_criteria.description: Identifies which factual differences would make a later case distinguishable from this authority, ideally as actionable bullet points for drafting or client counseling.
accepted_values: Clear, actionable distinguishing facts listed in practical terms
Some distinguishing factors identified but not fully actionable

sub_criteria.name: Predictive Guidance for Application
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary offers practical guidance about the likelihood the holding will apply to similar scenarios, including caveats and factors that increase/decrease applicability.
accepted_values: Practical, reasoned guidance on likely application provided with caveats

sub_criteria.name: Examples and Hypotheticals
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary provides short examples or hypotheticals that illustrate boundary conditions or clarifying contrasts.
accepted_values: One or two illustrative examples present

Litigation Professional.name: Practical Utility for Briefs and Motions
Litigation Professional.description: Evaluates whether the summary extracts practical takeaways (argument hooks, element-by-element mapping, suggested uses) that make the case directly usable in drafting motions or briefs, and whether it anticipates opposing arguments.

sub_criteria.name: Suggested Argument Uses and Sample Headings
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary suggests specific ways to use the case in argument and ideally provides sample point headings or phrasing for insertion into briefs.
accepted_values: Explicit suggested uses with sample headings/phrases provided and targeted to common contexts
Some suggested uses noted but without sample language
General hints at usage only without concrete language

sub_criteria.name: Element-by-Element Mapping to Claims/Defenses
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary maps judicial findings to specific elements of common claims/defenses so a practitioner can port aspects into briefing with minimal additional analysis.
accepted_values: Clear, element-by-element mapping provided with citations to holdings
Partial mapping present requiring some practitioner work
Minimal mapping requiring extensive reader work

sub_criteria.name: Identification of Favorable and Unfavorable Points
sub_criteria.description: Notes which parts of the decision favor typical plaintiff or defendant positions and which elements might be problematic to adopt, presented in a balanced way.
accepted_values: Balanced list of favorable and unfavorable points with brief explanation
Only favorable or only unfavorable aspects mentioned

sub_criteria.name: Suggested Counterarguments and Rebuttals
sub_criteria.description: Offers suggested counterarguments that opposing counsel might raise and concise rejoinders or limitations from the decision the drafter can use.
accepted_values: Specific likely counterarguments and concise rebuttals suggested
Some counterarguments anticipated with limited rebuttals
No suggestion of counterarguments or rebuttals

sub_criteria.name: Ready-to-Use Snippets and Pull Quotes
sub_criteria.description: Indicates whether the summary supplies short, citation-ready quotes or paraphrases labeled for brief insertion (e.g., 'Use this sentence as a heading').
accepted_values: Ready-to-use snippets and pull quotes labeled and pinpointed
A few useful snippets present but not labeled for insertion

Litigation Professional.name: Remedies, Orders, and Enforcement Detail
Litigation Professional.description: Evaluates whether the summary records the specific relief ordered, scope and terms of injunctions or orders, monetary awards and their basis, and any enforcement or implementation details included in the summary.

sub_criteria.name: Specificity of Remedy Description
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether remedies are described with essential terms (amounts, scope, duration, conditions) as included in the summary.
accepted_values: Remedy described with specific terms and figures where applicable
Remedy type noted but specifics missing
Only generic remedy reference without key terms

sub_criteria.name: Enforcement and Implementation Notes
sub_criteria.description: Notes whether the summary includes details on enforcement, stays, bonds, compliance monitoring, deadlines, or timelines as reported.
accepted_values: Enforcement and implementation details clearly included with timelines
Some enforcement details present but not exhaustive
Enforcement implied but not spelled out

sub_criteria.name: Monetary Award Basis and Calculations
sub_criteria.description: If monetary relief is present, assesses whether the summary explains the basis for calculation (formula, lost profits, statutory damages) and any relevant caps or offsets.
accepted_values: Damages amounts and calculation basis clearly explained and sourced

sub_criteria.name: Scope and Practical Effect of Injunctive Relief
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary captures the operative terms of injunctive relief (who is bound, geographic/scope limits, duration, mandatory v. prohibitory).
accepted_values: Injunction scope and practical effect clearly described
Injunction type noted but scope details limited
Injunction mentioned without sufficient operational detail

Litigation Professional.name: Quotations, Labeling of Holding vs. Dicta, and Context
Litigation Professional.description: Assesses whether the summary provides verbatim key quotations with pinpoints where helpful, explicitly distinguishes holding from dicta, and places quotes in context so they can be safely used in briefs.

sub_criteria.name: Holding vs. Dicta Labeling
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary explicitly labels material statements as holding or dicta and explains the basis for that classification where possible, reducing risk of misuse.
accepted_values: Clear labels and rationale for holding vs. dicta included
Some distinction made but explanation brief
No distinction between holding and dicta

sub_criteria.name: Key Verbatim Quotations with Pinpoints
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether verbatim excerpts of pivotal language are quoted and attributed with pinpoint references included in the summary.
accepted_values: Key quotations provided with pinpoints and clear labels
A few key quotations included but not comprehensive

sub_criteria.name: Contextual Labeling of Quotes
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether quoted material is accompanied by context (whose argument the court addressed, what issue the quote supports) to avoid mischaracterization.
accepted_values: Quotes fully contextualized to prevent misreading
Some context provided but could be clearer

sub_criteria.name: Accuracy and Completeness of Quotation
sub_criteria.description: Verifies that quotations are accurate (no substantive omissions) and that ellipses or brackets are used appropriately as indicated in the summary.
accepted_values: Quotations accurate with proper ellipses/brackets and attribution
Quotations mostly accurate but minor formatting/ellipsis issues
Quotations paraphrased or trimmed in a way that may mislead

Litigation Professional.name: Clarity, Conciseness, Formatting, and Navigability
Litigation Professional.description: Evaluates overall readability and organization: whether the summary uses standard headings (Issue, Facts, Holding, Reasoning, Disposition), is appropriately concise for complexity, formatted for rapid use by litigators, and includes metadata to support search and triage.

sub_criteria.name: Structure and Use of Headings
sub_criteria.description: Checks for a consistent structure with headings that allow a litigator to quickly locate Issues, Facts, Procedural History, Holding, Reasoning, and Disposition.
accepted_values: Well-structured with standard, clear headings enabling quick navigation
Structure present but uses some nonstandard headings
Some structure but inconsistent headings reduce navigability

sub_criteria.name: Length Appropriateness to Complexity
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the level of detail and length match the complexity of the case (concise for simple cases; fuller explanation for complex ones) and whether summary provides TL;DR or short capsule.
accepted_values: Length appropriate to complexity (concise but complete) with short capsule
Slightly verbose or slightly terse but generally serviceable
Mismatch between length and complexity (under- or over-detailed)
Inappropriate length (too long or too short) for practical use

sub_criteria.name: Formatting for Rapid Extraction
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates use of bullets, numbered issues, bolding, subheads and other visual cues that help extract citation-ready content quickly and enable skimming by busy practitioners.
accepted_values: Formatting optimized for rapid scanning (bullets, bolds, numbered items)
Some helpful formatting used though inconsistent
Minimal formatting; harder to scan quickly
No formatting to aid rapid use

sub_criteria.name: Plain Language and Readability
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the writing is clear, uses plain legal language suitable for litigators and support staff, and avoids unnecessary jargon or opaque phrasing.
accepted_values: Highly readable, plain-language suitable for litigators
Generally readable with occasional dense phrasing
Frequent jargon or dense prose reduces immediacy

sub_criteria.name: Metadata, Tags and Searchability
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary includes useful metadata (topic tags, practice area, issues, statutes) or short abstract to support search, triage, and filtering.
accepted_values: Basic metadata present but could be more detailed

Legal Education Community.name: Core Case Elements (IRAC and Procedural Posture)
Legal Education Community.description: Evaluates whether the summary explicitly and distinctly presents the fundamental elements needed for doctrinal teaching and IRAC practice: Issue(s), Rule(s), Application/Reasoning, Holding/Conclusion, and Procedural Posture. Focuses on identifiability and pedagogical usability of each element from the summary alone.

sub_criteria.name: Issue(s) Framed for Instruction
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the legal question(s) are stated in a way that supports classroom problem-spotting, discussion, or exam practice.
accepted_values: Explicit, sharply framed and pedagogically useful
Stated but broad or multi-part (usable after minor refinement)

sub_criteria.name: Rule(s) Clearly Identified
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether governing legal principles, tests, or statutory standards are isolated and stated clearly, enabling students to apply them in hypotheticals.
accepted_values: Rules stated precisely with key elements and caveats included
Rules present but missing some elements or nuance
Rules only implied within analysis, not stated outright

sub_criteria.name: Application / Reasoning Traceable
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary explains how the court applied the rule(s) to facts in a stepwise way that students can follow and critique.
accepted_values: Detailed, logical application that traces steps of reasoning
Sufficient but condensed application (major steps present)
Minimal application (conclusions stated without logical steps)

sub_criteria.name: Holding / Outcome Clear
sub_criteria.description: Checks that the court's holding (legal result and who prevailed) is explicit and distinguished from dicta or commentary.
accepted_values: Holding explicitly stated and clearly separated from dicta
Holding present but partly conflated with dicta/policy

sub_criteria.name: Procedural Posture Adequately Described
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary identifies the relevant court, appeal stage, standard of review, and how the case reached the decision being summarized.
accepted_values: Full procedural posture described (courts, prior rulings, posture, standard of review)
Partial procedural information (some stages or standard vague)
Procedural posture implied or incomplete (key step missing)

sub_criteria.name: Facts Selection and Relevance
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the facts included are the material facts necessary to understand the legal dispute and the court's reasoning (versus extraneous background).
accepted_values: Material facts prioritized; extraneous details omitted
Mostly relevant facts but some nonessential details present
Key material facts missing or buried among extraneous detail
Facts absent or primarily background noise

sub_criteria.name: Timeline and Facts Organization
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the chronology of events and causal relationships among facts are presented clearly (timeline, sequence of events).
accepted_values: Clear, chronological timeline or equivalent (easy to follow)
Generally chronological with occasional jumps or ambiguities

sub_criteria.name: Standard of Review and Burden Allocation
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary states the applicable standard of review and which party bore particular burdens (e.g., burden of proof, motion-specific burdens).
accepted_values: Standard of review and burdens clearly identified and applied
Standard or burden mentioned but not fully explained

sub_criteria.name: Relief, Remedy, and Practical Outcome
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary identifies the remedy awarded or the practical legal consequence (damages, injunction, reversal, remand) and why that remedy followed.
accepted_values: Remedy/practical outcome explicitly described with rationale
Outcome stated but remedy specifics or rationale incomplete
No mention of remedy or practical consequences

Legal Education Community.name: Clarity and Readability for Students
Legal Education Community.description: Assesses whether language, sentence structure, and explanations are clear and appropriate for the intended student audience, minimizing unnecessary jargon and cognitive load.

sub_criteria.name: Plain Language and Jargon Handling
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates use of plain language and whether legal terms are defined or explained at a level suitable for the target students.
accepted_values: Plain language with clear definitions for specialized terms
Mostly plain; occasional jargon but contextually understandable

sub_criteria.name: Sentence and Paragraph Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Assesses sentence length, paragraphing, and transitions to determine whether the text is easily readable and structured for student comprehension.
accepted_values: Concise sentences, clear paragraphs and transitions
Generally clear with some long or complex passages

sub_criteria.name: Target-Level Appropriateness
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether tone, depth, and scaffolding match the intended student level (e.g., 1L versus advanced seminar).
accepted_values: Well matched to the intended student level

sub_criteria.name: Clarity of Key Takeaways
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary highlights concise, memorable takeaways that students can retain for review or class discussion.
accepted_values: Key takeaways explicitly stated and easy to recall
Takeaways present but embedded in text

sub_criteria.name: Use of Examples, Analogies, and Illustrations
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether accessible examples or analogies are used to clarify abstract legal concepts or complex reasoning.
accepted_values: Effective, well-chosen examples/analogies that clarify concepts
Some examples present but unevenly applied
Limited or generic examples that add little clarity

sub_criteria.name: Supplementary Definitions and Footnotes
sub_criteria.description: Checks for in-text glosses, glossary entries, or helpful footnotes that explain arcane terms, statutory citations, or technical references.
accepted_values: Useful footnotes/glossary effectively clarify technical content
Some explanatory notes present but incomplete
Sparse or perfunctory notes offering limited help

sub_criteria.name: Readability Indicators (length/reading time)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether estimated reading time or readability cues (e.g., short summary lengths, word-count hints) are provided to help student planning.
accepted_values: Clear reading-time estimate and appropriate length guidance provided
Some indication of length but no explicit reading-time estimate
Length appears mismatched to stated purpose with no guidance

Legal Education Community.name: Organization, Navigation, and Signposting
Legal Education Community.description: Evaluates the document-level structure that facilitates quick instructor preparation and student skimming: headings, labeled IRAC elements, bullets, executive summary, and internal signposting.

sub_criteria.name: Sectioning and Headings
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether major components (facts, issue, rule, analysis, holding, significance) are separated with clear headings.
accepted_values: Explicit headings for all major components
Basic sectioning with some inconsistent headings
Continuous text with no meaningful sectioning

sub_criteria.name: Labeling for IRAC Practice
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether Issue, Rule, Application, and Conclusion are signposted or otherwise easily mapped for IRAC exercises.
accepted_values: IRAC elements clearly labeled or easily extractable
Elements present in order but not explicitly labeled

sub_criteria.name: Use of Bullets, Lists, and Callouts
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether visual devices (bullets, numbered lists, bolded callouts) are used to aid skimming and classroom use.
accepted_values: Effective, consistent use of lists/callouts to aid navigation
Some useful visual aids but not systematic

sub_criteria.name: Executive Summary / Abstract
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether a concise abstract at the top provides quick orientation with core facts, holding, and significance.
accepted_values: Clear executive summary covering facts, holding, significance
Short summary present but missing one core element
Only a headline or one-line summary

sub_criteria.name: Internal Signposting and Transitions
sub_criteria.description: Assesses topic sentences and transitions that guide the reader through the analysis without confusion.
accepted_values: Strong signposting and smooth logical transitions
Generally clear flow with occasional weak transitions

sub_criteria.name: Visual Aids (timelines, charts, maps)
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary uses visual representations (timelines, flowcharts, tables) to convey complex factual sequences or doctrinal relationships.
accepted_values: Clear, relevant visual aids that add explanatory value
Some visual aids present but limited in scope
Minor or poorly executed visuals with limited utility

sub_criteria.name: Document Navigation Features (TOC/anchors)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses presence of navigational tools for digital or print use (table of contents, internal links, bookmarks) to facilitate instructor/student use.
accepted_values: Basic navigation (headings) but no TOC or anchors
Limited navigation making quick lookup awkward

Legal Education Community.name: Citation and Bibliographic Metadata
Legal Education Community.description: Assesses whether the summary contains the essential citation and access metadata instructors and students need to locate and reference the case within teaching materials.

sub_criteria.name: Core Citation Elements
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates presence of case name, court, year, and jurisdiction.
accepted_values: Complete (case name, court, year, jurisdiction present)

sub_criteria.name: Reporter and Pinpoint Citations
sub_criteria.description: Checks for official reporter citations, parallel citations, and pinpoint references where relevant for classroom citation practice.
accepted_values: Full reporter and pinpoint citations provided
Only informal or web citation provided

sub_criteria.name: Neutral/Proprietary Citation and Stable Identifiers
sub_criteria.description: Assesses inclusion of neutral citations, vendor database IDs (e.g., Westlaw/Lexis), or stable public identifiers (court IDs) to ensure persistent access.
accepted_values: Neutral citation and stable identifiers included alongside vendor IDs
Vendor citation present; neutral/stable ID absent

sub_criteria.name: Access Information (Links/IDs)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether a reliable URL, database identifier, or guidance for locating the opinion is provided.
accepted_values: Direct URL or stable database identifier provided
General reference to source but no direct link
Access info vague or likely outdated

sub_criteria.name: Citation Formatting and Internal Accuracy
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the citation conforms to typical legal citation standards and contains internally consistent elements (no contradictory dates or court names).
accepted_values: Minor formatting inconsistencies but content accurate
Errors in citation elements that may confuse locating the case

sub_criteria.name: Suggested Excerpts / Pinpoint Guidance for Teaching
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary suggests particular page/paragraph excerpts from the opinion to assign for class discussion or close reading.
accepted_values: Helpful pinpoint recommendations for teaching excerpts included
Some suggested excerpts but not specific
No excerpt guidance though such guidance would aid teaching
No excerpt guidance and none recommended

Legal Education Community.name: Doctrinal Context and Precedential Relations
Legal Education Community.description: Evaluates whether the summary situates the case within its doctrinal area, explains relationships to precedent and doctrinal tests, and notes implications for doctrine and practice using only material contained in the summary.

sub_criteria.name: Doctrinal Placement
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary names the doctrinal area and subtopic and explains why the case belongs there.
accepted_values: Explicit doctrinal placement with brief justification
Doctrinal area named but not fully explained

sub_criteria.name: Relation to Precedent and Tests
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary explains how the case fits with, distinguishes, modifies, or overrules prior tests or precedent as described within the summary.
accepted_values: Clear explanation of relationship to precedent/tests
Mentions precedent/tests but lacks substantive linkage
No mention of precedent or doctrinal tests

sub_criteria.name: Practical and Doctrinal Implications
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary notes likely practical effects or doctrinal consequences for future cases or practice.
accepted_values: Explicit implications and likely downstream effects noted
Some implications noted but not fully explored

sub_criteria.name: Cross-Topic Relevance
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary identifies connections to other legal topics or interdisciplinary considerations helpful for broader classroom placement.
accepted_values: Explicit cross-topic links with useful examples
Some cross-topic references but limited depth
Only nominal or tangential cross-topic mentions

sub_criteria.name: Comparative and Jurisdictional Perspective
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary references how other jurisdictions or courts have treated the issue (comparative perspective) when relevant for doctrinal contrast.
accepted_values: Useful comparative references or contrasts provided
Some jurisdictional comparison but limited detail
Only a passing mention of other jurisdictions

sub_criteria.name: Historical and Statutory Background
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary gives enough statutory or historical background to understand the doctrinal development relevant to the case.
accepted_values: Concise statutory/historical context that aids understanding
Minimal background; reader must research context

Legal Education Community.name: Analytical Depth and Critical Commentary
Legal Education Community.description: Assesses whether the summary offers instructor-useful critical analysis (evaluation of reasoning, counterarguments, and policy considerations) that can seed classroom debate without requiring external materials.

sub_criteria.name: Evaluation of Court Reasoning
sub_criteria.description: Assesses the extent to which the summary critically examines the coherence and persuasiveness of the court's analysis.
accepted_values: Thorough, balanced critique highlighting strengths and weaknesses

sub_criteria.name: Identification of Counterarguments and Limits
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether plausible counterarguments, alternative readings, or limiting distinctions are provided for discussion.
accepted_values: One or two useful counterarguments or limits suggested
Only a mention that counterarguments exist

sub_criteria.name: Policy and Normative Analysis
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary integrates relevant policy rationales or normative reflections that illuminate stakes of the decision for classroom discussion.
accepted_values: Some policy references but not fully developed

sub_criteria.name: Instructor-Useful Insight and Discussion Prompts
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether commentary offers novel or pedagogically useful insights, distinctions, or prompts that an instructor can use to drive class discussion.
accepted_values: Original, provocative insights and ready-to-use prompts
Moderately useful commentary with some fresh points
Mostly descriptive with limited new insight

sub_criteria.name: Evidence and Support for Analytical Claims
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether analytical or normative claims are supported by citations to the opinion, precedent, or statutory text rather than unsupported assertion.
accepted_values: Analytical claims are well-supported with citations or textual references
Some claims supported, others asserted without clear backing
Many analytical claims lack adequate supporting references
Analytical claims are speculative and unsupported

sub_criteria.name: Scope of Critical Engagement (depth vs. breadth)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary chooses depth on central issues over superficial coverage of many peripheral points, in a way useful for classroom engagement.
accepted_values: Focused depth on central issues that fosters deep discussion
Good balance of depth and breadth with minor gaps
Broad but shallow coverage of many points

Legal Education Community.name: Pedagogical Features and Teaching Aids
Legal Education Community.description: Evaluates whether the summary contains explicit teaching supports—learning objectives, scaffolded discussion questions, hypotheticals, timing guidance, or instructor notes—that facilitate classroom implementation.

sub_criteria.name: Learning Objectives
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether explicit, measurable learning objectives are provided and aligned to the summary's content.
accepted_values: Clear, specific, measurable objectives aligned with content
General objectives present but not specific

sub_criteria.name: Discussion Questions and Scaffolding
sub_criteria.description: Assesses quality, range, and pedagogical sequencing of suggested discussion questions (from recall to synthesis).
accepted_values: High-quality, scaffolded questions of varying difficulty
Good questions but limited in scope or depth

sub_criteria.name: Hypotheticals and Application Exercises
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary includes hypotheticals or short exercises that enable students to practice applying rules and reasoning.

sub_criteria.name: Instructor Notes and Timing Guidance
sub_criteria.description: Assesses presence of brief facilitation notes, suggested assignments, estimated timing, or variations for different formats.
accepted_values: Comprehensive instructor notes with timing and options

sub_criteria.name: Answer Keys / Suggested Responses
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether suggested answers or model responses are provided for discussion questions and hypotheticals to aid instructors and graders.
accepted_values: Detailed answer keys or model responses available
Brief suggested answers or outlines provided
Hints only; no full model answers

sub_criteria.name: Difficulty Tagging and Audience Signals
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary is tagged for difficulty or intended audience (e.g., 1L, advanced seminar) to help instructors select appropriate materials.
accepted_values: Implicit indication of audience via content but not tagged
Unclear audience; instructor must infer suitability

sub_criteria.name: Suggested Classroom Activities and Variations
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary suggests concrete in-class activities (paired exercises, moot points, role-plays) or variations for different class sizes/modes.
accepted_values: Specific, practical classroom activity suggestions provided
General activity ideas with limited detail

Legal Education Community.name: Neutrality and Tone Appropriate for Teaching
Legal Education Community.description: Assesses whether the summary presents the case neutrally and objectively—fairly representing both sides, avoiding advocacy language, and neutrally summarizing any dissents or concurrences.

sub_criteria.name: Balance in Presenting Parties' Arguments
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether both parties' legal arguments and positions are fairly and accurately summarized for classroom debate.
accepted_values: Balanced, fair presentation of both sides
Mostly balanced with minor emphasis on one side

sub_criteria.name: Neutral Language and Avoidance of Bias
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether language avoids emotive, persuasive, or partisan wording that could bias student discussion.
accepted_values: Slightly evaluative language but largely neutral

sub_criteria.name: Fair Representation of Concurrences/Dissents
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether separate opinions are neutrally summarized and their reasoning captured without spin.

sub_criteria.name: Author Attribution and Conflicts
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether any author perspective, institutional affiliation, or potential conflicts of interest are disclosed so instructors can weigh interpretive slant.
accepted_values: Partial disclosure (affiliation noted but no perspective statement)
No disclosure though author perspective is apparent
No disclosure and perspective appears biased

Legal Education Community.name: Conciseness and Length Appropriateness
Legal Education Community.description: Assesses whether the summary's length and density are appropriate for classroom assignment or handout—concise enough for assigned reading while covering necessary substance.

sub_criteria.name: Overall Length vs. Target Reading Time
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary is sized to fit typical assigned reading windows for the intended use (e.g., brief handout vs primary reading).
accepted_values: Concise and fits target reading time while covering essentials
Slightly long but defensible given substance
Likely too long for assigned reading without trimming
Overlong and unsuitable as assigned reading

sub_criteria.name: Economy of Expression
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary avoids unnecessary repetition, tangential details, and verbosity.
accepted_values: Economical and focused with minimal redundancy
Some redundancy or tangential detail present

sub_criteria.name: Use of Summaries/Callouts to Reduce Reading Time
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether executive summaries, bullet-point takeaways, or boxed callouts enable efficient review.
accepted_values: Effective use of summaries and callouts for quick review

sub_criteria.name: Prioritization of Core vs Ancillary Details
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary clearly indicates which details are central to the holding and which are background, enabling instructors/students to triage reading focus.
accepted_values: Core details labeled or emphasized; ancillary facts minimized
Most core details emphasized though some ancillary remain prominent
No prioritization; reader must parse significance

sub_criteria.name: Word Count and Compactness Metrics Provided
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether word count, section lengths, or compactness indicators are provided to help instructors decide on assignment suitability.
accepted_values: Word count/section lengths provided and useful
Partial length indicators (e.g., summary only) provided
No formal metrics though length is apparent

Legal Education Community.name: Suitability as Primary vs. Supplementary Teaching Material
Legal Education Community.description: Judges whether the summary can reasonably serve as a primary assigned text, a supplementary handout, a quick review reference, or is unsuitable for classroom use without major additions.

sub_criteria.name: Standalone Completeness
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary provides sufficient content for students to understand the case and learning goals without reading the full opinion.
accepted_values: Complete and self-sufficient (suitable as primary reading)
Mostly complete but benefits from minor supplementary excerpts

sub_criteria.name: Need for Supplemental Materials
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary requires additional primary sources (full opinion, statutes) or secondary explanation to meet teaching objectives.
accepted_values: No supplements needed for stated objectives

sub_criteria.name: Adaptability Across Teaching Formats
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary is usable in lecture, seminar, small-group exercises, or exam-prep contexts with minimal modification.

sub_criteria.name: Utility as Review or Reference
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary functions well as a quick reference for students (concise takeaways, clear citation).

sub_criteria.name: Suggested Excerpts and Assignment Strategy
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary offers suggested assignment strategies (which parts to assign, alternatives for time-limited classes) to help instructors deploy it as primary or supplementary material.
accepted_values: Clear suggested excerpts and assignment plans provided
Some assignment guidance provided but not comprehensive
Minimal guidance; instructor must design assignment

Legal Education Community.name: Alignment with Learning Outcomes and Skills Training
Legal Education Community.description: Evaluates whether the summary explicitly supports common legal-education learning outcomes and skills (doctrinal comprehension, IRAC practice, appellate briefing, statutory interpretation, policy analysis) through its content and structure.

sub_criteria.name: Support for Doctrinal Understanding
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary enhances students' grasp of governing doctrine and legal tests.
accepted_values: Strongly supports doctrinal understanding with clear explanations
Moderately supports doctrine but omits some nuance

sub_criteria.name: Support for IRAC and Analytical Skills
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary is structured and detailed enough to permit IRAC practice and analytical exercises.
accepted_values: Explicitly structured to facilitate IRAC practice
Partially facilitates IRAC with some missing elements

sub_criteria.name: Support for Appellate Reasoning and Briefing
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary helps students learn issue-framing, appellate reasoning, and brief-writing techniques.
accepted_values: Clearly models appellate reasoning and brief-worthy issues
Some useful exemplars for appellate skills

sub_criteria.name: Support for Policy and Statutory Interpretation Skills
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary fosters policy analysis and statutory interpretation skills where relevant.
accepted_values: Strong integration of statutory interpretation and policy analysis
Some relevant references but limited depth
Only cursory mention of policy/statutory issues

sub_criteria.name: Mapping to Explicit Learning Outcomes and Assessments
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary explicitly maps its content to stated learning outcomes and suggests assessment tasks (quizzes, short writing prompts).
accepted_values: Clear mapping to learning outcomes and suggested assessments
Learning outcomes listed but assessment suggestions minimal
No explicit mapping; outcomes must be inferred
No learning outcomes or assessment guidance

Legal Education Community.name: Internal Consistency and Non‑Misleading Presentation
Legal Education Community.description: Assesses whether the summary is internally consistent, free of contradictions or unsupported assertions, and avoids presenting speculative or misleading statements as fact—based solely on the content of the summary itself.

sub_criteria.name: Factual Consistency Within the Summary
sub_criteria.description: Checks for internal contradictions in facts, dates, parties, procedural statements, or outcomes within the summary.
accepted_values: Minor inconsistencies that do not affect teaching use

sub_criteria.name: Distinction Between Court Statements and Commentary
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary clearly differentiates the court's statements from author commentary or speculation.
accepted_values: Clear demarcation between court holdings and author commentary
Frequent blending that could confuse readers

sub_criteria.name: Avoidance of Overclaiming or Speculation
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary avoids speculative claims about broader legal effects or facts not supported in the summary.
accepted_values: Occasional speculative phrasing but generally cautious

sub_criteria.name: Consistency with Quoted Text and Excerpts
sub_criteria.description: Checks that any quoted excerpts or paraphrases of the opinion accurately reflect the source and are not taken out of context in a misleading way.
accepted_values: Quotes and paraphrases faithfully reflect source context
Minor paraphrase imprecision but not misleading
Paraphrases that risk misrepresenting the source
Quotes/paraphrases that misstate or distort the opinion

sub_criteria.name: Versioning and Date Stamping
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary notes its own version/date and any updates so instructors know whether material reflects subsequent developments.
accepted_values: Clear version/date stamp and update notes provided
Date present but no detailed update history
No date/stamp though content appears current

Journalism & Media.name: Key Facts Coverage (Who/What/When/Where/Why/How)
Journalism & Media.description: Evaluates whether the summary supplies the essential factual elements reporters need to construct a lede and factual context, and whether those facts are specific and placed for quick extraction.

sub_criteria.name: Element Completeness
sub_criteria.description: Measures presence of the six core factual elements (who, what, when, where, why, how).
accepted_values: Complete — All six elements present and clearly identifiable
Mostly complete — Four or five elements present and reasonably clear
Partial — Two or three elements present or several are ambiguous
Minimal — Only one element present or most elements missing
None — No core factual elements present

sub_criteria.name: Specificity and Granularity
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether factual elements include concrete, reporter-usable details (full party names, precise dates, specific locations, quantification) rather than vague references.
accepted_values: Highly specific — Full names, exact dates, precise locations/amounts provided
Mostly specific — Key specifics provided but occasional approximations
General — Facts stated at a high level (e.g., 'last year', 'a company')
Vague — Facts are imprecise or use generic phrasing

sub_criteria.name: Placement and Prominence
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether core facts are presented in a journalist-friendly position (lead or top summary) or are buried, affecting extraction speed.
accepted_values: Lead-present — Core facts presented in a single lead or top summary
Top-weighted — Most facts appear near the beginning but some are lower down
Dispersed — Facts scattered throughout requiring synthesis
Buried — Key facts are deep in text or only in exhibits
Absent — No clear placement of facts

sub_criteria.name: Fact Attribution (source of factual claims)
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether factual assertions indicate their source (e.g., court opinion paragraph, filing, testimony) so reporters can verify origin.
accepted_values: Clearly attributed — Each significant factual claim cites a source
Mostly attributed — Most facts have at least general source attribution
Partially attributed — Some facts attributed; others lack source markers
Unattributed — Facts presented without indication of origin
Misattributed — Sources are incorrect or misleading

sub_criteria.name: Roles and Identity Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether parties' roles (plaintiff/defendant, appellant/respondent, victim/witness) and corporate/designated entities are unambiguously stated.
accepted_values: Explicit roles — All parties named with clear roles and short-form identifiers
Mostly clear — Roles are identifiable though some short-forms missing
Ambiguous — Some parties named but roles unclear or inconsistent
Only names — Parties named but roles not indicated

sub_criteria.name: Temporal Sequence / Chronology
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates if the summary sets out the sequence of events clearly enough for readers to understand how facts and legal steps unfolded over time.
accepted_values: Clear chronology — Events presented in an easy-to-follow, dated sequence
Mostly chronological — Order clear though some timing details missing
Fragmentary chronology — Some order but important gaps or reversals
Non-sequential — Events presented out of order or confusingly

sub_criteria.name: Materiality and Relevance Filtering
sub_criteria.description: Measures whether the summary highlights material facts germane to the decision and avoids distracting, low-relevance details.
accepted_values: Focus on material facts — Summary centers on relevant, case-determinative facts
Mostly material — Predominantly relevant facts, minor extraneous detail
Mixed relevance — Balance of material facts and trivial detail
Overly detailed — Too many low-value facts obscure the essentials
Missing material facts — Key determinative facts omitted

sub_criteria.name: Quantitative Evidence and Metrics
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether numeric facts (damages, dates, counts, measurements) are provided and presented unambiguously.
accepted_values: Numeric clarity — All relevant numbers given precisely (amounts, counts, dates)
Mostly numeric — Major numbers present; a few are approximated
Partial numbers — Some numeric data provided but others missing
Vague numbers — Quantities referenced only qualitatively
No numeric data — Numeric information absent

Journalism & Media.name: Outcome and Remedy Clarity
Journalism & Media.description: Assesses whether the summary states the court's disposition and any remedy or relief in an unambiguous, reporter-ready way.

sub_criteria.name: Disposition Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary clearly states the disposition (e.g., affirmed, reversed, vacated, remanded) concisely.
accepted_values: Explicit — Disposition plainly stated in one clear sentence
Clear but spread — Disposition present but requires synthesis across sentences
Ambiguous — Disposition described indirectly or contradictorily
Imprecise terminology — Uses nonstandard or confusing labels for disposition
Not stated — No clear disposition given

sub_criteria.name: Remedy/Relief Specificity
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates how specifically the summary explains the relief ordered (damages, injunction, remand instructions, dismissal) and whether amounts or actions are quantified.
accepted_values: Specific and quantified — Exact remedy and amounts or actions described
Specific but unquantified — Remedy type clear but lacks amounts or precise instructions
General — Relief indicated only at a high level
None — No mention of remedy or relief

sub_criteria.name: Operative Timing and Scope
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary specifies when the decision takes effect and whether it is limited in scope (e.g., interlocutory, binding beyond the parties).
accepted_values: Timing and scope explicit — Effective date and scope clearly stated
Scope clear, timing implicit — Scope stated but operative timing not explicit
Timing clear, scope vague — Effective date present but scope unclear
Both vague — Neither timing nor scope clearly explained
Not addressed — No information on timing or scope

sub_criteria.name: Legal Basis for Outcome
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary identifies the primary legal grounds or rule the court applied (statute, doctrine, or controlling precedent).
accepted_values: Explicit statutory/precedent basis — Clear reference to law or precedent forming the basis
General legal rationale — Court's rationale summarized but not linked to a specific authority
Vague rationale — High-level reasoning without clear legal anchor
Absent — No explanation of the legal basis
Incorrect — Stated legal basis is inaccurate or misleading

sub_criteria.name: Enforceability and Implementation Mechanics
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary explains how the remedy will be enforced or implemented in practical terms (timelines, responsible actors, required actions).
accepted_values: Clear mechanics — Implementation steps and responsible parties described
Partially described — Some implementation detail provided
Mentioned but vague — Enforcement referred to without operational details
Incorrect mechanics — Described process is wrong or misleading

sub_criteria.name: Appealability and Next Steps
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary indicates whether the decision is final, appealable, or subject to further proceedings and what likely next steps are.
accepted_values: Next steps explicit — Appealability and immediate procedural options clearly stated
Next steps implied — Hints about appeal/status but not explicit
Unclear — Uncertain whether decision is final or appealable
Not addressed — No mention of further procedure
Incorrect — Wrong statement about appealability or procedure

Journalism & Media.name: Holding and Procedural Posture
Journalism & Media.description: Evaluates whether the summary distinguishes the court's holding from procedural posture and explains the legal significance and applicability of the holding.

sub_criteria.name: Holding Identification
sub_criteria.description: Measures whether the summary states the holding (the legal rule or conclusion) clearly and succinctly.
accepted_values: Clear holding — Holding stated as a rule/conclusion usable in a lede
Present but mixed — Holding present but entangled with facts or procedure
Implicit — Holding must be inferred from reasoning

sub_criteria.name: Scope of Holding
sub_criteria.description: Determines whether the summary indicates how broadly the holding applies (narrowly to facts, limited to parties, or general precedent).
accepted_values: Scope explicit — Summary specifies limits or breadth of applicability
Scope implied — Hints at breadth but not explicit
Overbroad claim — Summary incorrectly generalizes holding
Not addressed — No mention of scope

sub_criteria.name: Procedural Posture Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary identifies the procedural posture (trial/appeal/interlocutory/en banc) and why that posture matters.
accepted_values: Clearly identified and contextualized — Posture named and relevance explained
Identified only — Posture named but no explanation of significance
Implied — Clues to posture exist but not named explicitly
Not stated — No procedural posture information
Incorrectly stated — Posture given but factually wrong

sub_criteria.name: Separation of Law vs. Procedure
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary keeps legal holdings distinct from procedural status to avoid conflating legal significance with the case stage.
accepted_values: Well separated — Holding and posture clearly delineated
Mostly separated — Minor overlaps but generally distinct
Blended — Holding and posture mixed together
Confused — Procedural details presented as legal rules (or vice versa)
Not addressed — No attempt to separate

sub_criteria.name: Binding Authority vs. Dicta
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary indicates whether the described rule is a binding holding, persuasive dictum, or tentative discussion.
accepted_values: Explicitly binding — Clearly labeled as binding holding
Labeled as dicta/persuasive — Identified correctly as non-binding commentary
Ambiguous status — Unclear whether rule is binding or dicta
Not addressed — No indication of binding status

sub_criteria.name: Rule vs. Application Distinction
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary separates the legal rule announced from the court's application of that rule to the facts.
accepted_values: Clearly separated — Rule and application presented distinctly
Mostly separated — Minor blending but discernible
Partially blended — Rule and application intermixed
Confused — Cannot distinguish rule from factual application

Journalism & Media.name: Case Identification Metadata
Journalism & Media.description: Evaluates presence and quality of standard metadata reporters need to attribute and locate the decision (court, date, parties, judge(s)/panel, docket/citation) without requiring external lookup.

sub_criteria.name: Court and Jurisdiction
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the issuing court and its jurisdictional level (trial, appellate, supreme; federal/state) are clearly stated.
accepted_values: Complete and clear — Full court name and jurisdictional level given correctly
Adequate — Court name present but jurisdictional level implied or abbreviated
Partial — Ambiguous or abbreviated court information

sub_criteria.name: Decision Date
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the exact decision date (or filing/entry date) is provided and unambiguous.
accepted_values: Exact date present — Full date provided (day, month, year)
Relative timing — Only relative timing (e.g., 'last week') given
Conflicting dates — Multiple, conflicting dates provided

sub_criteria.name: Party Names and Styling
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether full party names and conventional caption styling are present and whether short-form names or a reporter alias are supplied for use in stories.
accepted_values: Full names + reporter alias — Full official party names and suggested short names provided
Full names only — Full party names present but no short form suggested
Partial names — Abbreviated or one-party only
Ambiguous — Party identity unclear (initials only, generic labels)

sub_criteria.name: Judge(s)/Panel and Authorship
sub_criteria.description: Checks presence of judge names, authoring judge/opinion writer, and concurrences/dissents where relevant.
accepted_values: Complete — Panel, author, concurrences/dissents all listed
Mostly complete — Authoring judge listed; panel/dissent info partly given
Limited — Only one judge named or generic reference
Missing — No judge or panel information

sub_criteria.name: Docket/Citation (retrievability identifier)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether a usable citation (official reporter, neutral citation), docket number, or direct locator is provided so reporters can reference the decision.
accepted_values: Comprehensive — Official citation, docket number and/or neutral citation provided
Adequate — Citation or docket number present; link missing
Partial — Only an informal locator present
Minimal — Single ambiguous locator (e.g., case name only)
None — No citation or retrievable identifier

sub_criteria.name: Publication Status
sub_criteria.description: Indicates whether the opinion is published, unpublished, memorandum, or subject to sealing — important for citation and use.
accepted_values: Published — Officially published and citable in reporter
Published (electronic) — Has a neutral citation or electronic publication status
Not stated — No publication status provided

sub_criteria.name: Counsel and Representation
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary lists counsel for the parties and their affiliations where reporter attribution/use may matter.
accepted_values: Full counsel list — Lead counsel and firms/orgs for key parties provided
Partial counsel — Some counsel listed, particularly for lead parties
Limited — Only one or generic counsel reference

Journalism & Media.name: Readability and Media-Readiness
Journalism & Media.description: Measures how easily a journalist can extract a lede and background: presence of a media-ready lead, conciseness, sentence clarity, structure, and expected editing effort.

sub_criteria.name: Lead Sentence Quality
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary contains a journalist-ready single-sentence lede that captures the who/what/why/so-what.
accepted_values: Media-ready lede present — Strong single-sentence lede suitable for publication
Usable summary lead — Short multi-sentence summary usable with light edits
Weak lede — Attempted lead but incomplete or missing key elements
No lede — No summary lead provided
Misleading lede — Lead emphasizes trivial or inaccurate point

sub_criteria.name: Conciseness and Length
sub_criteria.description: Assesses overall length relative to information supplied and whether the summary is concise or overly verbose for quick reporting.
accepted_values: Efficient — Slightly long but focused and extractable
Verbose — Accurate but wordy; requires condensing
Overlong — Excessive detail that impedes quick reading
Fragmentary — Too short to be useful

sub_criteria.name: Sentence Clarity and Readability
sub_criteria.description: Measures sentence structure, grammar, and plain-English readability (active voice, sentence length, jargon).
accepted_values: Very clear — Short, direct sentences; minimal legalese
Clear — Mostly straightforward with occasional complex sentences
Mixed — Some clear sentences but notable complexity
Dense — Long, complex sentences that slow comprehension
Incoherent — Poorly written; hard to follow

sub_criteria.name: Organization and Signposting
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary uses headings, paragraphs, or signposts to separate facts, holding, and implications for quick scanning.
accepted_values: Well organized — Clear sections or signposts make scanning easy
Mostly organized — Some signposting present but could be clearer
Linear but unmarked — Information is logically ordered but not signposted
Poorly organized — Jumbled or repetitive structure

sub_criteria.name: Editing Effort Required
sub_criteria.description: Estimates the level of editing or rewriting a reporter would need to make the summary publishable.
accepted_values: Minimal — Ready to use with little to no editing
Light — Minor edits to tighten phrasing or clarify terms
Unsuitable — Not salvageable for media use without full rewrite

sub_criteria.name: Headline and Nut-Graph Suggestion
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary proposes a short headline and a one-paragraph nut-graph (contextualizing sentence) for immediate use in stories.
accepted_values: Headline + nut-graph present — Both a concise headline and nut-graph suggested
One present — Either headline or nut-graph suggested
Suggestive phrasing only — Elements implied but not explicit
Inappropriate — Suggested headline/nut-graph misleading or off-focus

sub_criteria.name: Quick-scan Elements (bullets/metadata tags)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary includes bullets, key-fact lists, or metadata tags to facilitate rapid scanning and downstream tagging.
accepted_values: Comprehensive bullets/tags — Useful key facts and tags provided
Some bullets — Partial list of key facts or a few tags
Minimal — One or two quick-scan elements
Incorrect tags — Tags/labels misleading or wrong

Journalism & Media.name: Quotability and Attribution
Journalism & Media.description: Assesses whether the summary supplies direct, attributable quotations and clear attribution language that reporters can use as sourced soundbites or ascribed claims.

sub_criteria.name: Presence of Direct Quotes
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary includes direct quotations from the opinion, parties, or counsel that are usable in reporting.
accepted_values: Multiple usable quotes — Several well-chosen, context-rich quotes included
One good quote — At least one clear, reporter-ready quote present
Short fragments only — Only brief or clipped quotations included
Paraphrase only — No direct quotes, only paraphrases

sub_criteria.name: Attribution Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Checks that quotes and assertions are clearly attributed (e.g., 'the court held', 'plaintiff argued') with source identification.
accepted_values: Explicit attribution — Every quote/assertion clearly linked to its source and role
Mostly clear — Most attributions present; a few ambiguous cases
Partial attribution — Some items attributed but notable gaps
Vague attribution — Source references general (e.g., 'according to filings')

sub_criteria.name: Quote Suitability and Length
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether included quotes are concise, salient, and appropriate as a soundbite or a lead excerpt.
accepted_values: Highly suitable — Quotes are concise, vivid, and newsworthy
Moderately suitable — Quotes useful but may need trimming
Limited suitability — Quotes are technical or long but salvageable
Poor suitability — Quotes are tangential or unclear
Unsuitable — Quotes not usable for reporting

sub_criteria.name: Attribution Precision (who said what)
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates the precision of attributions (distinguishes majority opinion vs. concurrence vs. party statement).
accepted_values: Precise — Distinguishes majority, concurrence, dissent, counsel, and parties
Generally precise — Most attributions differentiated correctly
Some ambiguity — A few attributions lack clear source role
Imprecise — Frequent ambiguity about source roles
Incorrect — Attributions are wrong or misleading
