sub_criteria.name: Quote Context and Integrity
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether each quote is presented with enough context (who said it, where in the opinion, surrounding explanation) to avoid misleading readers when excerpted.
accepted_values: Context provided — Quotes include attribution and paragraph reference or immediate context
Partial context — Attribution present but missing pinpoint citation
Minimal context — Bare quote with only general attribution
Out-of-context risk — Quote likely to mislead without additional context
Misleading extraction — Quote presented in a way that distorts meaning

Journalism & Media.name: Plain-Language Translation
Journalism & Media.description: Evaluates whether legal terms, doctrines, and technical concepts are explained in accessible language for a general audience without misrepresenting the law.

sub_criteria.name: Coverage of Key Legal Terms
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether important legal terms and doctrines central to the decision are defined or translated into plain language.
accepted_values: Comprehensive — All key legal terms clearly explained
Mostly covered — Most important terms explained; minor gaps
Partial — Only some key terms explained

sub_criteria.name: Accuracy of Simplification
sub_criteria.description: Checks that plain-language explanations preserve legal accuracy and do not oversimplify to the point of misstatement.
accepted_values: Accurate and faithful — Simplifications preserve nuance and accuracy
Generally accurate — Minor simplifications that do not change meaning
Risky simplification — Some loss of nuance that could mislead non-expert readers

sub_criteria.name: Use of Examples or Analogies
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether concise examples or analogies are used to clarify complex concepts for lay readers.
accepted_values: Useful examples provided — Clear, brief examples that illuminate concepts
Some helpful analogy — At least one example/analogy present
Limited examples — Examples exist but are weakly linked to concept
Inapt examples — Examples that confuse rather than clarify

sub_criteria.name: Jargon Density
sub_criteria.description: Measures the amount of unexplained legal jargon remaining in the summary.
accepted_values: Low — Little to no unexplained jargon
Moderate — Some legal terms remain but most are explained
Predominant legalese — Summary largely in technical legal language

sub_criteria.name: Readability Level (audience fit)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary's plain-language register matches the intended target audience (general public, business readers, legal professionals).
accepted_values: General-public friendly — Readable by nonlawyers with minimal background
Business/educated public — Accessible to general business audience
Mismatch — Register does not fit intended audience

Journalism & Media.name: Implications and News Significance
Journalism & Media.description: Assesses whether the summary articulates why the decision matters: practical consequences, affected stakeholders, market/policy impacts, and potential precedential effects.

sub_criteria.name: Specificity of Consequences
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary identifies concrete, actionable consequences (who will be affected and how).
accepted_values: Explicit and specific — Multiple concrete consequences identified with examples
Specific — At least one clear, concrete consequence described
General — Broad impacts suggested without concrete detail
Speculative — Only hypothetical or speculative impacts mentioned

sub_criteria.name: Stakeholder Identification
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary names affected stakeholder groups (consumers, businesses, government, specific industries, or communities).
accepted_values: Multiple stakeholders named — Clear listing of affected groups and roles
One stakeholder group named — At least one clear group identified
No stakeholders identified — Impact not linked to any group

sub_criteria.name: Precedential and Doctrinal Impact
sub_criteria.description: Determines whether the summary discusses potential effects on precedent, doctrinal law, or future litigation in a way useful for reporting.
accepted_values: Detailed precedent analysis — Clear explanation of doctrinal/precedential implications
Noted potential impact — Mentions precedent impact without deep analysis
Unclear relevance — Mentions precedent but connection vague
No mention — Does not address precedent or doctrinal effect
Incorrect claim — Overstates or misstates precedential effect

sub_criteria.name: Suggested Reporting Angles
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary indicates practical story angles or hooks reporters can use (policy angle, local impact, economic effects).
accepted_values: Multiple actionable angles — Several clear story hooks suggested
One useful angle — At least one suggested angle relevant to reporters
Vague suggestion — Generic idea offered without leverage
Inappropriate — Suggested angles irrelevant to likely audiences

sub_criteria.name: Geographic and Market Scope
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary identifies the geographical or market scope of impact (local, statewide, national, international, industry-specific).
accepted_values: Precisely scoped — Geographic/market scope explicitly stated
Mostly scoped — Scope implied with reasonable clarity
Vague scope — Broad references without precision
Local-only mention — Only extremely narrow local impact noted where broader relevance exists

sub_criteria.name: Likelihood / Probabilistic Assessment
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary differentiates between likely, possible, and speculative impacts and indicates confidence level where appropriate.
accepted_values: Clear probability assessment — Distinguishes likely vs speculative impacts and explains basis
Qualified — Notes some impacts as probable and others speculative
Unclear — Impacts described without indication of likelihood
Speculative-only — Mostly hypothetical impacts with no grounding
Misleading certainty — Presents speculative outcomes as certain

Journalism & Media.name: Neutrality, Tone, and Balance
Journalism & Media.description: Evaluates whether the summary maintains an objective, balanced tone appropriate for news reporting, avoiding advocacy, loaded language, or unqualified assertions.

sub_criteria.name: Overall Objectivity
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the voice of the summary is neutral and factual rather than persuasive or promotional.
accepted_values: Slightly evaluative — Occasional value judgments but largely factual
Notably slanted — Clear favoring of one side or policy stance
Advocacy tone — Explicit persuasive language or promotion

sub_criteria.name: Loaded or Emotive Language
sub_criteria.description: Checks for use of loaded adjectives, rhetorical devices, or emotive phrasing that could bias a news story.
accepted_values: No loaded language — Neutral word choice throughout
Moderate — Noticeable loaded wording in places
Frequent — Many emotionally charged or biased terms
Pervasive — Summary dominated by emotive language

sub_criteria.name: Balance of Perspectives
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary represents competing views (court majority, concurrence/dissent, parties) fairly and indicates when assertions are disputed.
accepted_values: Balanced — Multiple perspectives represented and labeled
Mostly balanced — Dominant view emphasized but others noted
Unlabeled claims — Statements presented without indicating dispute
Biased — Omits or misrepresents opposing views

sub_criteria.name: Use of Qualifiers for Uncertainty
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary uses appropriate qualifiers where uncertainty exists (e.g., 'alleged', 'according to the court') and avoids misleading definitives.
accepted_values: Appropriate qualifiers used — Uncertainty and sources properly qualified
Under-qualified — Some definitive claims lacking needed qualifiers
Over-qualified — Excessive hedging that obscures key facts
Misqualified — Incorrect qualifiers that misrepresent certainty

sub_criteria.name: Perspective Sourcing (who is represented)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary makes clear which facts/assertions come from which party, the court, or third parties, avoiding implicit endorsement.
accepted_values: Clear sourcing — All contested assertions labeled to their source
Mostly clear — Most contested assertions sourced
Partial sourcing — Some but not all claims sourced
No sourcing — Assertions presented without source references

Journalism & Media.name: Source Traceability and Internal Citations
Journalism & Media.description: Assesses whether the summary includes internal pointers (paragraph citations, statute references, exhibit identifiers) and retrievability guidance enabling verification and follow-up without outside inference.

sub_criteria.name: Opinion/Paragraph Citations
sub_criteria.description: Checks for specific citation to opinion sections, paragraph numbers, or page references supporting key factual and legal claims.
accepted_values: Detailed — Exact paragraph/section citations provided for key points
Sufficient — General section or page citations enabling follow-up
Limited — Occasional citations but many claims unreferenced
Incorrect — Citations provided but point to wrong passages

sub_criteria.name: Statute and Authority References
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether statutes, regulations, or controlling authorities relied upon are cited with sufficient detail for lookup.
accepted_values: Complete — Full statutory citations or case authorities provided
Adequate — Names or common citations given allowing lookup
Partial — Authority referenced but citation incomplete
Vague — Legal sources mentioned without usable citation

sub_criteria.name: Exhibit / Filing Identifiers
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether exhibits, appendices, or filings referenced are identified with exhibit numbers or filing identifiers so a reporter can find the record item.
accepted_values: Clear — Exhibit numbers/filing identifiers provided and matched to claims
Mostly clear — Some exhibits identified, others not
Partial — Generic references to filings without identifiers
Absent — No exhibit or filing identifiers
Incorrect — Exhibit references do not match record

sub_criteria.name: External Links and Retrievability Guidance
sub_criteria.description: Checks for working links, URLs, or concrete guidance (repository + docket + citation) to find the full opinion or filings online to facilitate verification.
accepted_values: Direct and working links — Full opinion and key filings linked
Locator provided — Citation and repository named but no direct link
Indirect — Search hints included (e.g., docket + court) but no link
Broken/incorrect link — Provided links or URLs do not work

sub_criteria.name: Access/Paywall Status
sub_criteria.description: Indicates whether the linked or referenced materials are freely accessible or behind paywalls, affecting a reporter's ability to verify.
accepted_values: Open access — Opinion and filings freely accessible
Partially accessible — Some items free, others paywalled or restricted
Restricted/Sealed — Materials inaccessible due to sealing or restricted access
Not specified — Access status not indicated

sub_criteria.name: Version and Date Pinpointing
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary specifies the exact version of the document cited (e.g., slip opinion vs. final reporter) and the date of that version.
accepted_values: Version and date clear — Slip/final status and date specified
Partly clear — Date given but version not specified
Imprecise — Vague reference to 'the opinion' without version/date
Absent — No version or date pinpointing

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Outcome Clarity
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Evaluates whether the summary unambiguously communicates the case result in ways a policy or advocacy stakeholder can rely on: identifies the prevailing and adverse parties, specifies the judgment/disposition (affirmed/reversed/remanded/settled), and describes the remedy or relief and its operative scope.

sub_criteria.name: Winner & Disposition Identified
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary explicitly names the prevailing and losing parties and states the disposition for the case (e.g., affirmed, reversed, remanded, dismissed, settlement).
accepted_values: Winner and main disposition clearly stated
Winner and full disposition across claims/parties clearly stated

sub_criteria.name: Remedies/Orders Specified
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the relief (injunction, damages, declaratory relief, costs, remand instructions, etc.) is described with sufficient terms relevant to policy (scope, duration, monetary amounts where relevant).

sub_criteria.name: Operative Scope Across Claims & Parties
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary explains whether dispositions apply broadly or only to particular claims, parties, or facts (e.g., class vs. individual relief; claim-specific rulings).
accepted_values: Scope described for major claims only
Comprehensive scope description across all claims/parties

sub_criteria.name: Enforceability and Implementation Mechanisms
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary explains how orders will be enforced or implemented (e.g., injunctive contours, monitoring, payment mechanics, deadlines).
accepted_values: Detailed enforcement plan including responsible actors and triggers

sub_criteria.name: Temporal & Conditional Elements of Outcome
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary identifies any time-limited elements (duration of relief), conditional triggers (e.g., compliance deadlines), or staged relief.
accepted_values: Clear description of key temporal/conditional elements
Detailed timeline and conditional triggers with implications

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Core Legal Reasoning and Application
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Assesses whether the summary identifies the controlling legal standards or tests, explains how the court applied those standards to the facts, and links reasoning to the outcome in a way useful for policy interpretation.

sub_criteria.name: Identification of Controlling Law/Standards
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary names the statutes, regulations, doctrines, or judicial tests the court used as the basis for its decision.
accepted_values: Standards/tests identified with nuance and citation

sub_criteria.name: Standard of Review
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary specifies the standard of review applied (e.g., de novo, clear error, abuse of discretion) and explains its impact on the analysis.
accepted_values: Standard named with basic impact discussion
Standard clearly named and its analytical consequences explained

sub_criteria.name: Application of Law to Facts
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary explains the court's analytical steps showing how the legal standards were applied to the specific facts and evidence in the case.
accepted_values: Detailed stepwise application linking facts to legal conclusions

sub_criteria.name: Use of Analogies, Policy Reasoning, or Distinguishers
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary captures how the court used analogies, policy considerations, or distinguished prior cases to reach its conclusion.
accepted_values: Detailed treatment of policy reasoning and distinguishing rationale

sub_criteria.name: Handling of Opposing Arguments and Dissent
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary notes how the court addressed counterarguments, salient defenses, concurrences, or dissents and whether those affect the legal holding.
accepted_values: Counterarguments/dissent summarized and their impact assessed
Detailed treatment showing how different opinions affect legal implications

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Policy & Regulatory Implications
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Evaluates the degree to which the summary translates the court's holding into concrete implications for policy, regulation, or administrative practice, including probable direction and scope of impact.

sub_criteria.name: Direct Policy Effects
sub_criteria.description: Assesses clarity about immediate, direct effects on laws, regulations, agency actions, or public programs.
accepted_values: Clear direct effects with mechanisms described
Detailed direct effects with examples and potential responses

sub_criteria.name: Regulatory / Agency Impact
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether implications for regulatory interpretation, agency guidance, enforcement priorities, or administrative procedures are identified and explained.
accepted_values: Specific administrative actions or rulemaking pathways identified

sub_criteria.name: Likelihood of Policy or Regulatory Response
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary gauges the probability that legislatures, regulators, or agencies will respond (e.g., rulemaking, guidance, statutes) and why.
accepted_values: Detailed probability estimate with contingencies and timelines

sub_criteria.name: Magnitude and Certainty of Impact
sub_criteria.description: Assesses how well the summary characterizes the likely scale and confidence of the policy impact (e.g., narrow vs. national, speculative vs. probable).
accepted_values: Nuanced assessment with probability ranges and key contingencies

sub_criteria.name: Practical Implementation Considerations
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary flags operational issues for regulators or implementers (costs, staffing, enforcement complexity) resulting from the decision.
accepted_values: Detailed operational implications with mitigation options

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Affected Stakeholders & Differential Effects
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Checks whether the summary identifies which populations, sectors, or institutions will be affected, how effects vary across groups or regions, and the practical consequences stakeholders may face.

sub_criteria.name: Stakeholder Identification
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary names the key stakeholder groups (e.g., affected communities, industries, government entities).

sub_criteria.name: Geographic & Jurisdictional Reach
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary specifies where the decision applies geographically and whether effects differ by jurisdiction (local, state, federal, multi-jurisdictional).
accepted_values: Geographic reach stated for major effects
Detailed mapping of jurisdictional reach and cross-jurisdiction implications

sub_criteria.name: Differential Impact Analysis
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary explains how different groups will be affected differently (e.g., by income, geography, sector) and why.
accepted_values: Detailed analysis of unequal effects with scenarios

sub_criteria.name: Secondary and Ripple Effects
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary considers downstream economic, social, or regulatory ripple effects (supply chains, market responses, enforcement shifts).

sub_criteria.name: Practical Consequences for Stakeholders
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary explains operational, compliance, financial, or behavioral consequences stakeholders will likely experience.
accepted_values: Detailed, quantified or scenario-based practical consequences

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Precedential and Systemic Significance
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Evaluates whether the summary assesses the decision's precedential weight and potential systemic effects on legal practice, litigation strategy, regulatory interpretation, or broader policy frameworks.

sub_criteria.name: Court Level & Bindingness
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary explains the decision's bindingness given the issuing court and jurisdiction (e.g., Supreme Court, federal circuit, state appellate).
accepted_values: Detailed assessment including interplay with other jurisdictions

sub_criteria.name: Clarity of Holding vs. Dicta
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary distinguishes between binding holdings and persuasive or non-binding statements (dicta) that should not control future cases.
accepted_values: Precise mapping of holdings vs. dicta with implications

sub_criteria.name: Novelty of Legal Question
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary indicates whether the decision addresses a novel legal question or applies well-established law.
accepted_values: Clear identification of novelty or routine nature

sub_criteria.name: Conflict with Other Precedent / Circuit Splits
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary identifies conflicts or alignment with other courts (circuit splits) and the implications for future appeals or Supreme Court review.
accepted_values: Detailed mapping of conflicts and likely resolution pathways

sub_criteria.name: Downstream Effects & Likelihood to Be Adopted
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary considers likely downstream changes (e.g., litigation tactics, regulatory updates) and the probability other actors will follow this decision.
accepted_values: Clear downstream effects and adoption likelihood discussed
Comprehensive forecast with conditions and counterfactors

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Actionability for Advocacy
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Assesses whether the summary provides concrete, prioritized, and feasible actions advocates or policymakers can take in response to the decision (short-term and long-term), including communication points and resource/timing considerations.

sub_criteria.name: Short-term Tactical Steps
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates presence of immediate, concrete actions relevant to advocacy (e.g., statements, emergency filings, outreach, coalition coordination).
accepted_values: Detailed short-term plan with suggested actors and timelines

sub_criteria.name: Long-term Policy/Legislative Recommendations
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary suggests specific longer-term policy, statutory, or regulatory responses and their rationale.
accepted_values: Specific actionable legislative/regulatory proposals with pathways

sub_criteria.name: Communication & Messaging Guidance
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary provides succinct talking points, headlines, or messaging tailored to different audiences and channels.
accepted_values: Concise prioritized messaging with suggested channels and sample language

sub_criteria.name: Resource/Capacity & Risk Assessment
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary evaluates resource needs, legal risks, costs, or capacity constraints for suggested advocacy actions.
accepted_values: Detailed resource estimates, risk matrix, and mitigation suggestions

sub_criteria.name: Prioritization & Feasibility
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether recommended actions are prioritized and assessed for feasibility (likelihood of impact, required partners, timelines).
accepted_values: Rank-ordered feasible plan with effort vs. impact assessment

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Neutrality, Transparency, and Confidence Signalling
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Evaluates whether the summary transparently distinguishes the court's statements from the author's interpretation, discloses perspective or limitations when appropriate, maintains an appropriate neutral tone for policy usage, and signals confidence/uncertainty where warranted.

sub_criteria.name: Separation of Fact, Holding, and Interpretation
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary clearly labels what are factual recitals, the court's holding, and any author interpretation or recommendations.
accepted_values: Clearly separated most of the time

sub_criteria.name: Disclosure of Perspective or Conflicts
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the author discloses relevant perspectives, organizational positions, or potential conflicts that could shape interpretation.
accepted_values: Comprehensive disclosure with explanation of mitigation

sub_criteria.name: Tone and Bias
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the language and framing are neutral or display advocacy slant that could mislead policy users.

sub_criteria.name: Hedging and Confidence Statements
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary appropriately qualifies uncertain inferences and differentiates firm holdings from plausible interpretations.
accepted_values: Explicit confidence levels and rationale for uncertainty

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Citations, Traceability, and Verifiability
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Checks whether the summary supplies sufficient citations, pinpoint references, statute/regulation identifiers, and references to related authorities so a reader can verify the summary's claims using only the materials available within the task context.

sub_criteria.name: Case and Source Citation
sub_criteria.description: Assesses presence of an unambiguous citation to the decision (case name, court, date, reporter/docket if available) and key primary sources referenced.

sub_criteria.name: Pinpointing & Quotations
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether key claims are linked to page/paragraph pinpoints or direct quotations to enable precise verification.
accepted_values: Quotes without cites or vice versa

sub_criteria.name: Statute/Regulation Identifiers
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether statutes or regulations are cited with section/subsection identifiers and version/date where relevant.
accepted_values: Complete statutory/regulatory references with amendment history notes

sub_criteria.name: Related Authorities and Contextual Links
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary references related precedent or authorities and situates the case within that network (citations or brief contextual notes).
accepted_values: Most relevant authorities cited and contextualized
Comprehensive authority network with contextual notes

sub_criteria.name: Accessibility of Sources (links/identifiers)
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether citations include machine-readable identifiers or links (where available) so users can quickly access the primary materials.
accepted_values: All primary sources include direct machine-readable links/identifiers

sub_criteria.name: Currency and Validity (Shepardization/Negative Treatment)
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary notes if key authorities remain good law (e.g., negative treatment, subsequent overruling) or provides indicators of currency.
accepted_values: Clear currency indicators for major authorities

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Clarity and Accessibility for Non-Legal Audiences
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Assesses whether the summary uses plain language, defines necessary legal terms, employs examples or analogies, and is organized for quick comprehension by policy-makers and advocates who lack deep legal training.

sub_criteria.name: Plain Language and Terminology
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates use of plain language and whether key legal terms are defined in simple terms.
accepted_values: Most key terms defined in plain language
All key terms defined with simple examples

sub_criteria.name: Structure and Readability
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary is organized with a clear executive summary, headings, bullets, and signposting to aid quick scanning and comprehension.
accepted_values: Excellent structure: concise executive summary, bullets, and clear signposting

sub_criteria.name: Use of Examples and Analogies
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary uses concrete examples or analogies to illustrate implications for different audiences or scenarios.
accepted_values: Multiple tailored examples/analogies for key audiences

sub_criteria.name: Visuals, Tables, and Structured Data
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary uses timelines, tables, flowcharts, or bullet matrices to present complex information more accessibly.
accepted_values: Poorly chosen visuals or one-off table
Multiple clear visuals/tables tailored to user tasks

sub_criteria.name: Audience Tailoring and Localization
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether content is adapted to the specific needs of target users (e.g., advocates, agency staff, lawmakers) with localized examples or sector-specific framing.
accepted_values: Multiple versions/sections tailored to distinct user types

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Uncertainties, Limits, and Monitoring Recommendations
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Evaluates whether the summary flags open legal questions, limitations on generalizing the decision, factual record gaps that affect interpretation, and suggests concrete monitoring or follow-up actions.

sub_criteria.name: Legal Ambiguities & Contested Points
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary identifies unsettled legal issues or areas where the court left questions unresolved.
accepted_values: Thorough identification with implications for each ambiguity

sub_criteria.name: Limits on Generalization
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary explains the extent to which the decision is narrow or broadly applicable, including jurisdictional or factual limits.

sub_criteria.name: Quantified Uncertainty & Contingency Triggers
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary, where appropriate, quantifies uncertainty (likelihood ranges) and names specific triggers (appeal, new facts, rulemaking) that would change implications.
accepted_values: Quantified likelihood ranges and explicit contingency triggers

sub_criteria.name: Monitoring & Further Analysis Recommendations
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary recommends what to monitor (appeals, rulemaking, enforcement) or what further analysis is needed and prioritizes those items.
accepted_values: Clear monitoring points and suggested analyses
Detailed prioritized monitoring plan with triggers and next steps

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Conciseness and Relevance of Detail
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Evaluates whether the summary balances brevity with the necessary policy-relevant detail: avoids unnecessary legal minutiae while including all information needed for policy decision-making and advocacy planning.

sub_criteria.name: Length Appropriateness
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the overall length matches policy user needs (not too long to read quickly, but not so short that it omits essentials).

sub_criteria.name: Relevance of Included Detail
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether details included are directly relevant to policy/advocacy purposes and free of distracting legal minutiae.
accepted_values: Too much technical detail relative to policy needs
All details are prioritized and directly relevant

sub_criteria.name: Executive Summary & Highlights
sub_criteria.description: Checks for a concise executive summary and highlight bullets that enable rapid understanding and decision-making.
accepted_values: Excellent concise executive summary with prioritized bullets

sub_criteria.name: Prioritization for Different User Needs
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary signals which elements are most critical for different user types (e.g., quick action vs. deep legal review).
accepted_values: Clear priorities for multiple user types
Explicit, user-specific priority pointers and quick-action checklists

Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.name: Timing, Procedural Status, and Urgency
Policy & Advocacy Stakeholders.description: Assesses whether the summary clearly states dates, procedural posture (appeals, stays), when rulings take effect, and whether it indicates the urgency or windows for action for advocates and policymakers.

sub_criteria.name: Decision Date and Effective Date
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary includes the opinion date and when any parts of the decision take effect or become enforceable.
accepted_values: Explicit timelines with recommended urgency of response

sub_criteria.name: Appeal, Stay, and Enforcement Status
sub_criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary reports appeal filings, stay orders, or enforcement suspensions that affect whether immediate action is necessary.
accepted_values: Comprehensive procedural timeline with next-step implications

sub_criteria.name: Immediate Compliance or Operational Impact
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether the summary identifies any immediate compliance obligations, required operational changes, or other time-sensitive impacts.
accepted_values: Detailed immediate steps and timelines for compliance

sub_criteria.name: Alignment with Policy/Legislative Cycles
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary situates timing relative to relevant policy or legislative calendars (e.g., upcoming sessions, rulemaking windows) so advocates can time responses.

Public Self-Help Users.name: Relevance to User's Issue
Public Self-Help Users.description: Evaluates how closely the case summary matches the legal problem a self-help user faces, including the legal claim, factual pattern, relief sought, procedural posture, and whether the legal context is time-appropriate.

sub_criteria.name: Legal-Issue Match
sub_criteria.description: Degree to which the case involves the same legal claim, statute, or core legal question a user is likely to face.
accepted_values: Exact match (same claim/statute and central question)
Strong match (same claim type; minor doctrinal differences)
Partial match (related principle but different primary claim)

sub_criteria.name: Factual Pattern Similarity
sub_criteria.description: How closely the key facts (relationships, actions, timelines) align with those a typical self-help user would present.

sub_criteria.name: Relief/Remedy Correspondence
sub_criteria.description: Whether the remedy awarded or sought (damages, injunction, dismissal, etc.) corresponds to what a user would expect or seek in a similar situation.
accepted_values: Remedy closely corresponds to typical user need
Remedy mostly corresponds with minor variance
Remedy related but not directly applicable

sub_criteria.name: Procedural-Stage Relevance
sub_criteria.description: Whether the case's procedural posture (e.g., trial, appeal, motion) matches the stage a self-help user is likely to be in or could reasonably reach.
accepted_values: Same procedural stage as typical user scenario

sub_criteria.name: Temporal Relevance
sub_criteria.description: Whether the decision and legal context are current enough to apply to the user's situation (e.g., not superseded by later law).
accepted_values: Mostly current with minor temporal differences
Some outdated elements that may matter

sub_criteria.name: User Persona Alignment
sub_criteria.description: Degree to which the summary is targeted to the intended user type (self-help litigant, small-business owner, pro se, or lawyer) in tone, depth, and actionable content.
accepted_values: Clearly tailored to the stated user persona
Mostly aligned with small adjustments needed
Not aligned to any user persona

sub_criteria.name: Area-of-Law Specificity
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary identifies sub-fields or practice nuances (e.g., landlord-tenant within contract law) relevant to the user's narrower problem.
accepted_values: Generally in correct sub-field with minor gaps
Broad area identified but lacks sub-field detail

Public Self-Help Users.name: Key Facts and Parties
Public Self-Help Users.description: Assesses whether the summary gives the essential facts, identifies the parties and their roles, presents a clear timeline, distinguishes material facts from background, provides relevant context, and flags ambiguous or missing facts.

sub_criteria.name: Essential Facts Identified
sub_criteria.description: Whether core facts determining the outcome (dates, key actions, relationships) are included.

sub_criteria.name: Timeline Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Whether events are presented in a clear order that lets a reader follow how the dispute developed.

sub_criteria.name: Party Identification and Roles
sub_criteria.description: Whether parties are named and their roles (plaintiff/defendant, appellant/appellee) are clear.

sub_criteria.name: Materiality Distinction
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary highlights legally material facts and separates them from minor or background details.
accepted_values: Material facts clearly distinguished from background
Some material facts noted but others omitted

sub_criteria.name: Contextual Background
sub_criteria.description: Whether relevant contextual information (industry norms, contract terms, prior relationship) that affects legal analysis is provided.
accepted_values: Some context missing but core remains understandable

sub_criteria.name: Ambiguities and Missing Facts Flagged
sub_criteria.description: Whether gaps in the record or disputed facts that could change the outcome are explicitly noted.
accepted_values: All important ambiguities noted with potential impact
No ambiguities or missing facts acknowledged

sub_criteria.name: Evidence Linkage to Facts
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary indicates what evidence supports key facts (e.g., contract clause, witness testimony) or notes absence of corroboration.
accepted_values: Clear linkage of facts to specific evidence or record citations
Most key facts linked to supporting evidence
Some facts referenced with general evidence cues

Public Self-Help Users.name: Legal Issues and Governing Rules
Public Self-Help Users.description: Evaluates if the summary states the legal question(s), accurately explains the controlling rule/test/statute, references key authorities, uses plain language, and explains the rule's scope and limits.

sub_criteria.name: Issue Statement Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary identifies the precise legal question(s) the court decided.
accepted_values: Issues mostly clear with minor ambiguity
Issues generally stated but not precise

sub_criteria.name: Rule/Standard Accuracy
sub_criteria.description: Whether the governing legal rule, test, or standard is described accurately and at a level a lay reader can usefully understand.
accepted_values: Rule stated precisely and accurately in accessible terms
Rule mostly accurate with minor omissions
Rule stated but lacks precision or plain-language framing

sub_criteria.name: Authority Referencing
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary identifies the main statutes, cases, or regulations relied upon and explains their role.
accepted_values: Key authorities cited and their role explained
Major authorities cited; role broadly described

sub_criteria.name: Plain-Language Explanation
sub_criteria.description: Whether legal concepts and tests are translated into accessible language and, where helpful, illustrated with simple examples.
accepted_values: Clear plain-language explanations with helpful examples
Basic explanation but some concepts unexplained

sub_criteria.name: Scope and Limitations of Rule
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary explains how broadly the holding applies and notes important exceptions or limits.
accepted_values: No mention of scope or limitations

sub_criteria.name: Burden and Standard Allocation
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary identifies which party bore the burden (e.g., burden of proof, prima facie) and the applicable standard (preponderance, clear and convincing, reasonable doubt, summary judgment standard).
accepted_values: Burden and standard clearly and accurately identified
Incorrect or confusing statement about burden/standard
No mention of burden or standard

sub_criteria.name: Counterarguments and Dissent
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary acknowledges major counterarguments, concurring/dissenting opinions, or alternative interpretations the court considered.
accepted_values: Counterarguments/dissent summarized and their impact explained
Major counterpoints noted with some explanation
Some counterarguments mentioned but lightly treated
No mention of counterarguments or dissent

sub_criteria.name: Policy and Practical Rationale
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary explains policy reasons or practical factors the court relied on that could affect applicability to other contexts.
accepted_values: Policy/practical rationale clearly explained and tied to holding

Public Self-Help Users.name: Outcome and Remedy Clarity
Public Self-Help Users.description: Assesses if the summary clearly states who prevailed, the specific remedy or order, whether the decision is final or interlocutory, and the practical enforceability of the relief.

sub_criteria.name: Winning Party Identified
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary clearly indicates which party won at the relevant stage.

sub_criteria.name: Remedy/Relief Specified
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary gives the specific remedy (amount of damages, injunction terms, dismissal) or describes it with useful detail.

sub_criteria.name: Stage and Finality Noted
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary specifies if the outcome is final, interlocutory, or subject to further review and explains why that matters to a user.
accepted_values: Stage/finality clearly stated and implications explained

sub_criteria.name: Enforceability and Practical Effect
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary comments on how likely the remedy is to be enforced and practical barriers to obtaining relief (collection, injunction compliance).
accepted_values: Enforceability and practical effects clearly discussed

sub_criteria.name: Quantitative Specificity
sub_criteria.description: Degree to which monetary awards, deadlines, or other quantifiable terms are given with concrete numbers or measurable terms.

sub_criteria.name: Conditionality and Compliance Requirements
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary explains conditions attached to the remedy (e.g., compliance steps to obtain relief, stay conditions, bond requirements).
accepted_values: Conditionality and compliance requirements fully explained
Most conditions described with minor omissions
No mention of conditionality or compliance

Public Self-Help Users.name: Practical Implications and Risk Assessment
Public Self-Help Users.description: Translates the legal outcome into practical consequences for a self-help user: how strong a similar claim/defense might be, how small factual changes could affect outcome, realistic chances, and non-legal impacts (cost, time, reputation).

sub_criteria.name: Strength of Legal Position
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary communicates how persuasive or weak the legal holding would make a similar claim or defense, with appropriate caveats.
accepted_values: Clear, calibrated assessment of strength with caveats

sub_criteria.name: Applicability to Variant Facts
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary explains how the holding applies to close but not identical facts and identifies fact changes likely to alter the result.
accepted_values: Detailed discussion of applicability across variants
No guidance on applicability to different facts

sub_criteria.name: Likelihood/Probability Communication
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary frames chances and risks realistically (qualitatively or quantitatively) and avoids implying unjustified certainty.
accepted_values: Risks and likelihoods clearly and cautiously communicated

sub_criteria.name: Non-Legal Consequences
sub_criteria.description: Whether practical non-legal impacts (financial cost, time, reputational risk, emotional burden) are noted for self-help decision-making.

sub_criteria.name: Estimated Cost and Time Ranges
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary provides realistic ranges or examples for likely costs and expected timeframes to resolution for a similar case.
accepted_values: General cost/time estimates given with qualifiers

sub_criteria.name: Mitigation and Avoidance Strategies
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary suggests feasible steps to reduce risk (negotiation, documentation practices, alternative dispute resolution) tailored to likely users.

Public Self-Help Users.name: Actionable Next Steps for Self-Help Users
Public Self-Help Users.description: Assesses whether the summary offers clear, non-personalized, practical next actions a self-help user can take (evidence to gather, deadlines to check, resources to consult), and warns when legal counsel is advisable while including safety and non-advice disclaimers.

sub_criteria.name: Specific Evidence to Gather
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary lists concrete documents, witnesses, or preservation steps a user should collect.
accepted_values: Detailed and prioritized evidence checklist provided
Some evidence examples but not comprehensive

sub_criteria.name: Deadlines and Procedural Checks
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary alerts users to typical deadlines, statutes of limitation, filing windows, or procedural checks they should verify.
accepted_values: Clear deadlines and how to verify them provided
Important deadlines noted with limited detail

sub_criteria.name: Non-Legal Resource Referrals
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary points to accessible community resources, government forms, self-help centers, and reputable informational sources.
accepted_values: Concrete and appropriate resource referrals provided

sub_criteria.name: When to Seek Legal Counsel
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary gives clear, non-prescriptive guidance on circumstances where consulting an attorney is advisable.
accepted_values: Clear guidance on when counsel is recommended

sub_criteria.name: Safety, Privacy, and Non-Advice Disclaimers
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary includes appropriate disclaimers that it is informational (not personalized legal advice) and flags safety/confidentiality concerns where relevant.
accepted_values: Appropriate disclaimers and safety flags present

sub_criteria.name: Prioritization and Feasibility of Steps
sub_criteria.description: Whether suggested next steps are prioritized (what to do first) and feasible for typical self-help users (cost/time/skill considered).

sub_criteria.name: Templates, Forms, and Sample Language
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary includes or points to sample forms, templates, or plain-language scripts a self-help user can adapt.

Public Self-Help Users.name: Plain-Language Readability and Accessibility
Public Self-Help Users.description: Evaluates whether the summary is written and formatted for non-lawyers: minimizes unexplained jargon, uses clear sentences, includes examples, and presents content in a skimmable layout suitable for average adult readers.

sub_criteria.name: Jargon Use and Explanation
sub_criteria.description: Whether legal terms are minimized and, when used, defined in simple language or illustrated by examples.
accepted_values: Minimal jargon; all terms explained clearly

sub_criteria.name: Sentence and Paragraph Complexity
sub_criteria.description: Assesses sentence length, paragraph density, and overall ease of reading for lay audiences.
accepted_values: Very concise sentences and reader-friendly structure
Generally clear with occasional dense passages
Mostly complex prose difficult for lay readers

sub_criteria.name: Use of Examples and Analogies
sub_criteria.description: Whether simple examples or analogies are used to illustrate abstract legal concepts and likely outcomes.

sub_criteria.name: Formatting for Skimming and Accessibility
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary uses headings, bullets, short paragraphs, and other formatting that help quick scanning and accessibility (e.g., readable fonts, clear contrast).
accepted_values: Accessible reading level and skimmable formatting

sub_criteria.name: Readability Metrics and Estimated Reading Time
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary provides or conforms to recognized readability measures (e.g., grade level) and gives an estimated time to read for lay users.
accepted_values: Readability metrics provided and reading time short/appropriate
Generally readable with an estimate provided
No readability consideration or reading-time estimate

sub_criteria.name: Accessibility Features (alt text, ARIA, screen-reader friendly)
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary includes features that support users with disabilities (alt text for images, logical heading order, text-only/print-friendly view).
accepted_values: Full accessibility features present and documented

Public Self-Help Users.name: Citations and Source Transparency
Public Self-Help Users.description: Assesses whether the summary provides clear citation details and links so users can locate the full opinion or related authorities and understand the source's accessibility and reliability.

sub_criteria.name: Completeness of Citation
sub_criteria.description: Whether the case name, reporter or neutral citation, year, and court are provided in a recognizable form.

sub_criteria.name: Direct Link to Source
sub_criteria.description: Whether a working link to the full opinion or an official source is provided or a clear path to find it is suggested.
accepted_values: Direct, working link to full opinion provided
Link provided but may require subscription
Link to secondary source or summary only

sub_criteria.name: Pinpoint References
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary gives pinpoint citations (page, paragraph, or section) for key holdings or quoted language to help verification.
accepted_values: Pinpoint citations provided for key points

sub_criteria.name: Source Accessibility Noted
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary indicates if the referenced source is publicly accessible or behind paywalls and suggests alternatives if possible.
accepted_values: Accessibility clearly indicated and free source provided where possible
Mostly paywalled sources with no note

sub_criteria.name: Citation Format Consistency
sub_criteria.description: Whether citations follow a consistent and recognizable format that makes locating sources easier for non-expert users.

sub_criteria.name: Source Reliability and Type
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary distinguishes official primary sources (opinions, statutes), secondary sources (treatises, blogs), and indicates reliability.
accepted_values: Primary/secondary sources clearly labeled with reliability notes
Main source types identified; reliability mostly clear
Some source-type distinction but limited reliability cues

Public Self-Help Users.name: Jurisdiction and Precedential Value
Public Self-Help Users.description: Assesses whether the summary identifies the court and jurisdiction, explains whether the case is binding or persuasive for readers in other forums, and provides signals of the case's authority.

sub_criteria.name: Court and Jurisdiction Identification
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary states the exact court, jurisdiction (state/federal), and court level (trial, appellate, supreme).
accepted_values: Court identified; minor jurisdiction detail missing
Jurisdiction broadly stated but not specific

sub_criteria.name: Binding vs Persuasive Value
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary explains if the case is binding on readers in the same forum or merely persuasive elsewhere, and under what conditions.
accepted_values: Bindingness and persuasive value clearly explained

sub_criteria.name: Geographic and Topic Scope
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary notes the geographic reach (e.g., statewide, federal circuit) and topical limits of the holding.
accepted_values: Geographic and topic scope clearly described
Mostly clear scope with some ambiguity
Scope generally implied but not explicit

sub_criteria.name: Authority Signals
sub_criteria.description: Whether indicators of the case's authority (published/unpublished, en banc, later citations) are noted to help users judge weight.
accepted_values: Authority indicators clearly provided and explained

sub_criteria.name: Cross-Jurisdictional Applicability
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary helps users in other jurisdictions evaluate persuasive value and necessary adjustments to rely on the case.

Public Self-Help Users.name: Structure, Navigation, and Discoverability
Public Self-Help Users.description: Evaluates whether the summary is organized with clear headings and sections, offers a concise executive summary for quick comprehension, uses lists/visuals to present key points, and includes metadata or tags to aid search and retrieval.

sub_criteria.name: Logical Sectioning and Headings
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary uses clear, standard sections (e.g., Facts, Issues, Holding, Reasoning, Implications) that aid navigation.
accepted_values: Clear, standard headings that aid navigation
Mostly clear headings with minor gaps

sub_criteria.name: Concise Executive Summary (TL;DR)
sub_criteria.description: Whether a brief, plain-language executive summary or TL;DR is provided up front for quick understanding.
accepted_values: Brief summary present but could be clearer
Short summary included but lacking key details

sub_criteria.name: Use of Bullets, Lists, and Visual Aids
sub_criteria.description: Whether bullets, numbered lists, or simple tables are used to make key information easy to scan.
accepted_values: Some use of lists but inconsistent

sub_criteria.name: Metadata, Tags, and Search Keywords
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary includes useful metadata (topic, statute, jurisdiction, tags) to help users find related materials or filter results.
accepted_values: Useful tags present but could be expanded

sub_criteria.name: Skimmability and Highlighting
sub_criteria.description: Whether key takeaways, holdings, and next steps are clearly highlighted for someone skimming the page.
accepted_values: Key points clearly highlighted and easy to scan
Most key points visible on skim
Some key points visible but buried

sub_criteria.name: Table of Contents and Print-Friendly View
sub_criteria.description: Whether the page offers a quick table of contents or anchors for navigation and a clean print-friendly or text-only version.
accepted_values: One of TOC or print view provided

sub_criteria.name: Mobile/Responsive Layout
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary is easily readable and navigable on mobile devices and adapts layout effectively.
accepted_values: Mostly usable on mobile with minor issues

Public Self-Help Users.name: Limitations, Assumptions, and Confidence
Public Self-Help Users.description: Assesses whether the summary explicitly states its limits, discloses important assumptions, distinguishes holdings from dicta, and communicates uncertainty or confidence appropriately so users understand risks of overgeneralizing.

sub_criteria.name: Explicit Limitations and Caveats
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary warns against overgeneralizing the case beyond its facts, jurisdiction, or procedural quirks.
accepted_values: Comprehensive limitations and clear caveats provided
Some important limitations and caveats noted
Few limitations mentioned; some risk of overgeneralization

sub_criteria.name: Assumptions Disclosed
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary identifies assumptions it relies on (unchallenged facts, legal standards assumed) that readers should verify.

sub_criteria.name: Holdings vs Dicta Distinguished
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary differentiates between the court's binding holding and persuasive commentary or dicta.

sub_criteria.name: Confidence and Uncertainty Communication
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary communicates degrees of certainty and warns that outcomes may vary under different facts or law changes.

sub_criteria.name: Intended Audience and Scope Statement
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary explicitly states for whom it is intended (e.g., self-represented litigants, paralegals, attorneys) and any scope limitations.
accepted_values: Intended audience and scope clearly stated

Public Self-Help Users.name: Timeliness and Update Information
Public Self-Help Users.description: Evaluates whether the summary provides decision and other key dates, notes subsequent history or later treatment, indicates whether statutes/doctrines remain current, and shows when the summary was last reviewed or updated.

sub_criteria.name: Decision and Key Dates Provided
sub_criteria.description: Whether the decision date and other relevant dates (transaction dates, statute effective dates) are clearly included.

sub_criteria.name: Subsequent History and Treatment
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary notes any subsequent appeals, rehearings, or later citation history that affects the case's authority.
accepted_values: Subsequent history and treatment clearly summarized

sub_criteria.name: Statutory/Doctrinal Currency
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary indicates if the controlling statute or doctrine has been amended, superseded, or otherwise changed since the decision.
accepted_values: Mention of possible changes but no detail

sub_criteria.name: Last Review/Update Timestamp
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary shows when it was last reviewed or updated so users can judge timeliness.
accepted_values: Review date present but not prominent
Date present but stale/older without context
Date missing though update likely needed

sub_criteria.name: Update Mechanism and Frequency
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary indicates how updates will be made (manual editorial review, automated alerts) and typical refresh frequency.
accepted_values: Update mechanism documented and frequent reviews scheduled
Update mechanism noted with occasional reviews
Updates ad hoc with no schedule

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Core Case Elements Completeness
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Evaluates whether the summary includes the essential components needed for large-scale legal analysis and feature extraction: parties, procedural posture, material facts, legal issues/claims, holding/disposition, remedies, and the court's reasoning. Each component is inspected independently to allow precise failure modes.

sub_criteria.name: Parties Identified
sub_criteria.description: Checks whether plaintiff/claimant, defendant/respondent and relevant third parties (e.g., intervenors) are explicitly named, role-labeled, and distinguishable for entity linking.
accepted_values: Explicit but inconsistently named or missing role labels
Explicit, clearly distinguished with role context provided

sub_criteria.name: Procedural Posture and History
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the stage of litigation (trial/appeal/motion), prior rulings, and immediate procedural steps are stated so the decision can be placed in context.
accepted_values: Stated but lacking intermediate history or key prior rulings
Clearly and explicitly stated with relevant prior procedural history

sub_criteria.name: Material Facts
sub_criteria.description: Determines whether factual predicates necessary to interpret legal issues are present and whether decisive facts are explicitly linked to the holding.
accepted_values: Some facts present but multiple key facts missing or unclear
Most material facts present; minor contextual gaps remain
Comprehensive and relevant facts explicitly linked to legal issues

sub_criteria.name: Legal Issues / Claims (Framing)
sub_criteria.description: Checks that the precise legal questions, statutory provisions or common-law claims at issue are specified and framed to support classification and labeling.
accepted_values: Vaguely described or paraphrased without legal labels
Specified but incomplete or lacking statutory/citation references
Clearly and exhaustively specified with legal framing and references

sub_criteria.name: Holding / Disposition
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the court's decision and final disposition (who prevailed, remedy type, dismissal/affirmation/reversal) are present and unambiguous.
accepted_values: Implied only or buried in narrative
Stated but lacking specifics (e.g., who prevailed or remedy details)
Explicit, specific and unambiguous (who prevailed, disposition type)

sub_criteria.name: Remedies and Relief
sub_criteria.description: Determines whether any relief (damages, injunctions, declaratory relief, costs) and their scope/quantification are stated with sufficient specificity.
accepted_values: Described but lacking quantification or scope detail
Fully described with type, scope, and quantification where applicable

sub_criteria.name: Reasoning / Rationale Presence
sub_criteria.description: Measures whether the summary captures the court's principal legal reasoning and grounds, including the rules/tests applied and the link from facts to law.
accepted_values: Surface-level rationale without linkage to facts/tests
Substantive reasoning present but with gaps or unstated inferential steps
Detailed, traceable reasoning that links law, tests, and facts

sub_criteria.name: Standard of Review (where applicable)
sub_criteria.description: Whether the applicable appellate/trial standard of review (de novo, clear error, abuse of discretion, statutory standard) is identified and applied in the summary.
accepted_values: Named but not clearly tied to the outcome
Explicitly named and applied where relevant

sub_criteria.name: Key Dates within Factual Narrative
sub_criteria.description: Whether material events in the facts include date references (e.g., incident date, contract date) so temporal causality is clear.
accepted_values: Some dates referenced but many key events undated
Most key facts include dates but some are ambiguous
All material events include precise dates or clear temporal markers

sub_criteria.name: Statutory/Regulatory References in Core Elements
sub_criteria.description: Whether statutes or regulations central to the claims/holding are explicitly cited alongside the core elements (not only in citations section).
accepted_values: Referenced indirectly (e.g., 'under statute') but no section cited
Statutes cited in some core elements but inconsistently
Statutory/regulatory provisions explicitly cited in relevant core elements

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Outcome Labeling and Taxonomy Conformance
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Evaluates the presence, granularity, and standardization of an explicit outcome label (separate from the narrative), and whether it includes metadata (date, appeal status) and is mappable to an outcome taxonomy for quantitative analysis.

sub_criteria.name: Outcome Label Presence
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary exposes an explicit, discrete outcome label suitable for programmatic extraction.
accepted_values: Outcome only in narrative (no discrete label)
Outcome labeled inconsistently or in informal phrasing

sub_criteria.name: Outcome Label Granularity
sub_criteria.description: How fine-grained the outcome label is (binary win/lose vs. dismissal with prejudice, partial award, settlement, remedy details).
accepted_values: Fine-grained (remedy type, partial outcomes, settlement terms)

sub_criteria.name: Conformance to Outcome Taxonomy
sub_criteria.description: Whether outcome labels conform to or are readily mappable to a documented taxonomy/ontology (internal or external) to enable aggregation.
accepted_values: Directly conforms or uses documented standard codes

sub_criteria.name: Outcome Metadata (date, appeal status, certainty)
sub_criteria.description: Whether outcome labels include standardized metadata such as effective date, appeal pending/closed, and any stated certainty qualifiers.
accepted_values: Most relevant metadata present but not standardized
Complete, standardized metadata (date, appeal status, certainty)

sub_criteria.name: Outcome Provenance and Attribution
sub_criteria.description: Whether the source of the outcome label (e.g., court text, annotator, automated classifier) is recorded and whether the label indicates if it is inferred or explicitly stated.
accepted_values: Source indicated but not detailed (human vs automated)
Clear provenance with explicit source and inference flag

sub_criteria.name: Outcome Normalization / Canonical Code
sub_criteria.description: Whether the outcome is represented as a canonical code or normalized value that supports unambiguous aggregation across datasets.
accepted_values: Mostly normalized with some local codes
Canonical standardized codes used for outcomes

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Issue/Topic Tagging Granularity
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Assesses whether legal issues are tagged in a machine-usable way: presence of tags, their granularity (doctrinal vs. specific elements), support for multi-labeling, and adherence to a hierarchical taxonomy enabling topic modeling and classification.

sub_criteria.name: Tag Presence
sub_criteria.description: Whether any topical or issue tags are present and exposed as discrete fields.
accepted_values: Tags present for main issues but not comprehensive
Tags present for all relevant issues

sub_criteria.name: Tag Granularity
sub_criteria.description: Whether tags are high-level areas or include specific doctrines, statutory subsections, or claim elements useful for feature extraction.

sub_criteria.name: Multi-label and Overlap Support
sub_criteria.description: Whether multiple tags per case are supported and consistently used where issues overlap.
accepted_values: Multi-label consistently used for major overlaps

sub_criteria.name: Taxonomy/Hierarchy Use for Tags
sub_criteria.description: Whether tags adhere to a published taxonomy or hierarchy that enables aggregation at multiple levels.
accepted_values: Informal grouping but no formal hierarchy

sub_criteria.name: Tagging Method Transparency
sub_criteria.description: Whether the method used to assign tags (manual annotation, automated classifier, hybrid) is recorded and whether tag confidence or provenance is provided.
accepted_values: Method recorded with some provenance but no confidence scores
Method fully documented with provenance and confidence scores

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Terminology Standardization and Concept Mapping
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Assesses whether legal terms, synonyms, jurisdictional variants and acronyms are normalized or explicitly mapped to controlled vocabularies/ontologies to support semantic aggregation across cases.

sub_criteria.name: Controlled Vocabulary / Ontology Mapping
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary uses or maps terms to a controlled vocabulary or ontology for legal concepts.
accepted_values: Mostly mapped to an internal vocabulary
Consistently mapped to a recognized controlled vocabulary/ontology

sub_criteria.name: Synonym and Variant Normalization
sub_criteria.description: Whether synonyms, jurisdictional variants and alternate phrasings are normalized or explicitly mapped to canonical concepts.

sub_criteria.name: Abbreviation and Acronym Resolution
sub_criteria.description: Whether abbreviations and acronyms are expanded or linked to definitions to avoid ambiguity in automated processing.
accepted_values: All abbreviations and acronyms resolved and defined

sub_criteria.name: Cross-jurisdiction Concept Alignment
sub_criteria.description: Whether jurisdiction-specific concepts are mapped to cross-jurisdiction equivalents to facilitate comparative analyses.
accepted_values: Ad hoc mapping for a few concepts
Many concepts mapped but gaps remain

sub_criteria.name: Vocabulary Versioning and Change Tracking
sub_criteria.description: Whether the vocabulary/ontology versions used for mapping are recorded and whether change history is available to interpret mappings over time.
accepted_values: Version and date recorded but no changelog
Versioned vocabularies with documented changelog and dates

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Citation Completeness and Parsability
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Checks whether statutory, case, or secondary authority citations are present, complete, consistently formatted, and include machine-resolvable identifiers to enable automated extraction and linking.

sub_criteria.name: Citation Completeness
sub_criteria.description: Whether citations include bibliographic elements sufficient to uniquely identify the authority (reporter/volume/page, year, statutory section).

sub_criteria.name: Pinpoint References
sub_criteria.description: Whether pinpoint references (page, paragraph, section identifiers) are included for fine-grained linking.

sub_criteria.name: Citation Format Consistency
sub_criteria.description: Whether citations follow a consistent style or structured format that supports pattern-based parsing.

sub_criteria.name: Machine-linking / Identifier Presence
sub_criteria.description: Whether citations include machine-resolvable links or structured identifiers (URLs, DOIs, internal IDs) enabling automated linking to source texts.
accepted_values: Most citations have links/IDs but not all

sub_criteria.name: Citation Context Linking
sub_criteria.description: Whether each citation is connected to the claim or sentence it supports (in-text anchors) rather than listed in a separate bibliography only.
accepted_values: Some in-text citations but many separated
Most citations linked to supporting claims
Each citation explicitly linked to its supporting claim or sentence

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Temporal and Jurisdictional Metadata Quality
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Evaluates presence, precision, and standardization of temporal metadata (decision date, filing date) and jurisdiction/court-level metadata needed for temporal and cross-jurisdictional analyses.

sub_criteria.name: Decision Date Presence and Precision
sub_criteria.description: Whether the decision date is present and provided at sufficient precision (full ISO-like date preferred).

sub_criteria.name: Other Event Dates
sub_criteria.description: Presence and standardization of other relevant dates (filing, hearing, judgment enforcement) that contextualize procedural timing.
accepted_values: Some event dates present but incomplete
Most relevant dates present but not standardized
Comprehensive event dates present and standardized

sub_criteria.name: Jurisdiction and Court Level
sub_criteria.description: Whether jurisdiction (country/state) and court level (trial/appellate/supreme) are present, unambiguous and labeled using controlled terms.
accepted_values: Jurisdiction or court level present only
Jurisdiction and court present but nonstandard labels
Jurisdiction and court level present and standardized

sub_criteria.name: Date and Jurisdiction Standardization
sub_criteria.description: Whether dates and jurisdiction fields use normalized formats or controlled vocabularies enabling cross-case comparison.

sub_criteria.name: Court Identifier Codes and Granularity
sub_criteria.description: Whether explicit, machine-usable court identifiers (e.g., court registry codes, normalized court IDs) and court-level granularity are provided.
accepted_values: Court names with occasional standardized IDs
Standardized court IDs and clear court-level granularity provided

sub_criteria.name: Time Zone and Locale Normalization
sub_criteria.description: Whether timestamps/dates include locale/time-zone context where relevant (useful for cross-jurisdictional event ordering).
accepted_values: Locale or time-zone provided for some timestamps
All timestamps normalized with locale/time-zone metadata

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Entity Normalization and Identifiers
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Assesses whether key entities (party names, judges, courts, organizations) are normalized, disambiguated and, where possible, associated with stable identifiers to facilitate deduplication and linking across records.

sub_criteria.name: Party Name Normalization and IDs
sub_criteria.description: Whether party names are provided in canonical form (consistent casing, stripped noise) and mapped to unique IDs if available.
accepted_values: Fully normalized and mapped to unique IDs

sub_criteria.name: Judge/Court Name Consistency
sub_criteria.description: Whether judge names and court names are consistently represented and disambiguated across the summary.

sub_criteria.name: Organization/Agency Identifiers
sub_criteria.description: Whether referenced organizations/agencies include canonical names or identifiers (registry numbers, standard IDs).
accepted_values: All relevant orgs linked to canonical IDs

sub_criteria.name: Alias and Former-name Recording
sub_criteria.description: Whether aliases, former names or alternate spellings are recorded to enable robust entity linking.

sub_criteria.name: External Authority Linking
sub_criteria.description: Whether entities are linked to external authority records (e.g., business registries, judge directories, ORG/ID services) to enhance disambiguation.
accepted_values: Occasional external links for major entities
Many entities linked to external authorities
Extensive linking of entities to authoritative external records

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Machine-Readability and Structured Formatting
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Measures the extent to which the summary is presented in machine-consumable form (discrete fields, consistent headings, valid markup, and available structured exports) to support automated ingestion and large-scale processing.

sub_criteria.name: Fielded Metadata Exposure
sub_criteria.description: Whether key metadata and labels (title, court, date, parties, issues, outcome) are exposed as discrete, machine-readable fields rather than only embedded in prose.
accepted_values: Most key fields present but not fully standardized
All key metadata present as discrete fields

sub_criteria.name: Section Headings and Template Consistency
sub_criteria.description: Whether consistent headings or templates (e.g., Facts, Issues, Holding) are used across summaries to ease automated parsing.
accepted_values: Generally consistent template with some deviations

sub_criteria.name: Markup and Parsability Quality
sub_criteria.description: Quality of structural markup (well-formed XML/JSON/HTML), consistent tag use, and absence of markup errors that would impede automated parsing.
accepted_values: High-quality, well-formed markup suitable for automated parsing

sub_criteria.name: Export Formats and Schema Documentation
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary is available for export in machine formats (JSON, XML, CSV) and whether export schemas/documentation are published to enable consistent ingestion.
accepted_values: Export possible but only semi-structured (e.g., HTML)
Export in common structured formats but limited schema documentation
Well-documented exports in structured formats (JSON/XML/CSV) with schema

sub_criteria.name: API / Programmatic Access
sub_criteria.description: Whether summaries are accessible programmatically (APIs, bulk download endpoints) with documentation, authentication, and rate limits described.
accepted_values: Robust programmatic access with full docs and bulk export support

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Annotatability and Labeling Support
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Evaluates the degree to which the text supports addition of annotations and labels at document, section, sentence and token levels via stable anchors, offsets, and provenance metadata required for supervised learning and evaluation.

sub_criteria.name: Sentence and Token Boundary Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Whether sentence boundaries and tokenization-friendly text are present to support NLP annotation (minimal OCR artifacts, clear punctuation).
accepted_values: Boundaries present but inconsistent (OCR artifacts, run-ons)
Clear boundaries for majority of text

sub_criteria.name: Section/Paragraph IDs and Offsets
sub_criteria.description: Whether sections/paragraphs include stable unique IDs or character offsets to anchor annotations reliably across versions.
accepted_values: Offsets present but not stable across versions
Comprehensive, stable IDs and offsets for annotation anchoring

sub_criteria.name: Label Granularity Support
sub_criteria.description: Whether the format supports token-level, sentence-level and document-level labels simultaneously and cleanly.

sub_criteria.name: Annotation Provenance and Versioning
sub_criteria.description: Whether annotations can carry provenance (annotator/tool ID, timestamp) and the source document supports versioning to track changes and enable reproducible experiments.
accepted_values: Full provenance and stable versioning for annotations

sub_criteria.name: Tooling Format Compatibility
sub_criteria.description: Whether exported/structured annotation formats are compatible with common annotation tools and frameworks (e.g., BRAT, doccano, CoNLL, spaCy).
accepted_values: Limited compatibility with a single tool
Compatible with several common tools but with conversion steps
Directly compatible with major annotation tools/formats

Academic & Data-Science Researchers.name: Ambiguity, Uncertainty and Conflict Annotation
Academic & Data-Science Researchers.description: Determines whether the summary explicitly marks uncertain facts, contested points, conflicting narratives, and whether contested facts are attributed — information important for modeling label noise and building confidence estimates.

sub_criteria.name: Explicit Uncertainty Markers
sub_criteria.description: Whether contested/uncertain statuses (e.g., 'alleged', 'disputed') are explicitly marked in the text.
accepted_values: Uncertainty implied but not explicitly marked
Some explicit markers for key contested points
Explicit and systematic marking of uncertainty

sub_criteria.name: Conflicting Claims Flagging
sub_criteria.description: Whether mutually exclusive narratives or conflicts between parties are flagged or summarized for downstream handling.
accepted_values: Some conflicts noted but not reconciled
All conflicting claims systematically flagged and described

sub_criteria.name: Source Attribution for Contested Facts
sub_criteria.description: Whether contested facts are attributed to their origin (party, affidavit, exhibit) so researchers can weight or filter signals appropriately.
accepted_values: No source attribution for contested facts
Partial attribution for some contested facts
Most contested facts have source attributions
All contested facts have clear source attribution

sub_criteria.name: Confidence Annotations / Scores
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary supplies confidence annotations, probabilistic metadata, or explicit certainty qualifiers for key findings and labels.

sub_criteria.name: Distinction Between Legal and Factual Uncertainty
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary distinguishes uncertainty about factual predicates from uncertainty about legal interpretation/application.
accepted_values: Mostly distinguishes legal vs factual uncertainty
